title: cecil rhodes statue oxford who was
story: The decision to remove the infamous statue of Rhodes comes following protests over his links to Britains colonial past as part of the wider Black Lives Matter movement.Cecil Rhodes was a th century mining magnate who helped Victorian Britain colonise much of Southern Africa and held opinions that now offend modern values.Rhodes was one of the eras most famous imperialists, with Rhodesia - now Zimbabwe - and Zambia named after him.  Born in Bishops Stortford in , he was a sickly child before heading to Africa aged .He grew cotton before moving into diamond mining, founding the De Beers firm.As Prime Minister of the Cape Colony from  to , his government restricted the rights of black Africans by setting financial qualications for voting.He attended Oriel College in . On his death in  the Rhodes Scholarship was set up to help non-British students study at Oxford.Rhodes Scholars include Bill Clinton and three former Australian PMs.The focus of attention is on the statue which is above the entrance to Oriel College, part of Oxford University.The Rhodes Memorial Museum was established in his home town of Bishops Stortford in  but has since changed its name to the Bishops Stortford Museum.The town also has an Arts Centre and road named after him.A protest group called Stortford Against Rhodes has been set up to rename both. It currently has more than , signatures.The cottage in Muizenberg where he died is a provincial heritage site in the Western Cape Province of South Africa.A Rhodes Memorial stands on what is said to have been his favourite spot on Devil’s Peak in Cape Town.Rhodes University College, now Rhodes University, is in Grahamstown, which was set up in his name by trustees.A bronze statue of Rhodes sitting on his horse stands in Kimberley, Northern Cape, which was erected in .The statue marking the le of Cecil Rhodes has long been a contentious issue. As an imperialist and colonist, the legacy of Rhodes has come under intense scrutiny in recent years.He believed the English were the first race in the world and worked hard to extend British influence worldwide, saying: The more of the world we inhabit the better it is for the human race. Campaigners say Rhodes was a white supremacist.A previous campaign to have the statue removed in  was rejected.The Rhodes Must Fall Oxford campaign group previously called for the image of the controversial mining magnate and empire builder to be removed from Oriel College, arguing the university has failed to address its institutional racism.Demonstrators have protested in front of the Rhodes statue on the High Street in Oxford as part of the Black Lives Matter movement.An open letter from campaigners to the universitys vice-chancellor claims the institution has only made inconsequential inroads into tackling the material legacy of imperialism, adding it is not enough.Oxford West and Abingdon MP Layla Moran said, while she did not endorse vigilante action, the statue must come down.She said: The statues of white supremacists and slave merchants should not still be standing in our cities. Thats why the statue of Cecil Rhodes must come down.Im not endorsing vigilante action - but I would urge Oriel College in the strongest terms to think about what message this statue sends in , and to remove it.However, following protests the college said it had recommended to take down the statue and added that consultations will now take place into the issue and Rhodes legacy.Rhodes suffered ill health throughout his relatively short le.His heart condition ed when he was  with increasing severity until his death from heart failure in , aged , at his seaside cottage in Muizenberg.To mark his death the South African government organised a train to travel from the Cape to Rhodesia with it stopping at every station so mourners could pay their respect.He was eventually buried at World’s View, a hilltop some  miles from Bulawayo in Rhodesia, now Zimbabwe.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: britain recession coronavirus come together
story: THERE’S no sugar coating it. This country is about to be hit by a brutal recession.Businesses up and down the country have already closed their doors for the last time.⚠️ Read our coronavirus live blog for the latest news  updatesAnd a new report suggests unemployment could be on track to top million — the highest rate since the Great Depression.Butwe can come together as a country now, it’s not too late to mitigate the damage.Ordinary Brits who can afford to do so should hit the high street this week. Buying a new gadget or pair of shoes might not feel that patriotic, but by splashing a bit of cash you’ll be breathing le into Britain’s flatlining economy.The Government, too, must do its bit.Britain’s lowest skilled workers will need the most support to get back into work, so what better moment to invest in proper adult training programmes For our part, The Sun has launched Bounce Back Britain — a major new campaign backed by the PM which is designed to get businesses, people and communities back on their feet.Watch out for practical employment advice and a host of money-saving offers in the paper over the weeks and months ahead.This summer, our country is at a crossroads.Either we ignore reality and bask in the sunshine while the Britain we know collapses around us.Or we face up to the grim facts — and do everything we can to get the show back on the road.LABOUR MP Jess Phillips is absolutely right.Domestic abusers don’t discriminate, so why should the law discriminate against their victims All sufferers of domestic violence deserve protection.But due to a quirk in the law, some immigrant women are turned away from shelters because they can’t access public funds.Leaving a violent partner takes guts.A bureaucratic loophole cannot be used to send women back to their abusers.HIGH streets may be reopening — but public loos remain firmly closed.It takes the proverbial that anyone caught short on a trip to the shops will be forced to simply cross their legs.Local councillors must reopen our WCs.Of course, it’s unfair that councils have to stump up the cost of running facilities — and a whacking great tax on top of that.Chancellor Rishi Sunak should do his bit and close the bizarre loophole in the law which means public loos are subject to business rates.But someone needs to sort it out soon — or we’ll all be tying ourselves in knots.To receive The Sun’s Coronavirus newsletterevery tea time, sign up here.To follow us on Facebook, title: kids back school government drive opinion
story: It is sickening that .million have " rel"noreferrer noopener"barely done a scrap of homework — that it has not been set nor marked.⚠️ Read our coronavirus live blog for the latest news  updatesWhat are those schools playing at, aside from backing the unions’ destructive campaign to keep them shut And why are most secondary pupils now being fobbed off with a single short meeting with their teacher before summer, and only then “where possible” That is shockingly unambitious on the part of " rel"noreferrer noopener"Education Secretary Gavin Williamson.Some schools have, in fairness, performed admirably, setting several hours’ daily work online. Why weren’t they all ordered to do so Yes, a minority of disadvantaged kids have no computer access. That should have been the priority of both their schools and the Government.Abandoning them has widened disastrously the gap between them and other pupils and between the state and private systems.The Government must show far more drive, first by facing down the unions who used children as cannon fodder.Second, by scrapping" rel"noreferrer noopener" the -per-class limit and halving the crippling, unscientic two-metre rule. There is so little evidence either is necessary.Get our kids back to school.INSTEAD of smashing ancient statues and igniting a vicious culture war, let’s build new ones of more BAME achievers.It’s not our idea. It’s Boris Johnson’s. And we heartily agree. Let’s honour the first BAME holders of our great offices of State. The greatest BAME sportsmen and women — or scientists, academics or medics. The first black US President.That is a far more powerful statement about black lives mattering than toppling long-forgotten slavers or daubing " rel"noreferrer noopener"brainless abuse on Churchill.Meanwhile, let us take heart from the new poll that shows Britain is far more welcoming to dferent ethnicities than even just ten years ago.Of course we can do more — and the PM’s new racial inequality commission aims to pinpoint exactly what.What a pity the Left can only sneer at it.FOR the first time in a decade we dread today’s unemployment figures.They will be the first real evidence of the mountainous task facing the Chancellor as he creates the low-tax conditions for a new jobs boom. We’ll need it.We congratulate those who queued for hours to shop yesterday, though.Every purchase helps save someone’s job. Too many seem to think we can cower in our homes shopping online until Covid burns out or is nullied by a vaccine.Do that and we will emerge to find only ghost towns and millions on handouts.To receive The Sun’s Coronavirus newsletterevery tea time, sign up here.To follow us on Facebook, simply ‘Like’ our Coronavirus page.Get Britain’s best-selling newspaper delivered to your smartphone or tablet each day – find out more.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: boris marcus rashford free school meals plea
story: The PM today declared that free school meals WILL be extended over the summer holidays, after a heroic campaign by England striker Marcus Rashford.Its a move that will benefit millions of disadvantaged families. And it couldnt come at a greater time of need: with our nation on the brink of the worst ever holiday hunger.The Covid pandemic has had a devastating financial impact on families up and down the country, with millions now struggling to keep a roof over their heads.Parents are, understandably, racked with anxiety over job losses, loved ones health and school closures, which have seen classrooms lie empty for  weeks.And this week, with the summer holidays looming, they faced another worry: how would they feed their children without free school meal vouchers Its a fear Rashford has bravely alleviated.The Man Utd star made an impassioned plea to the Government to prioritise Englands most vulnerable kids by extending the vouchers scheme over the six-week holidays.Under the programme, the families of around . million children eligible for free school meals are given £ a week in vouchers to spend in supermarkets to keep their kids fed.This is not about politics this is about humanity, Rashford wrote in an open letter. Political affiliations aside, can we not all agree that no child should be going to bed hungry The footballer was speaking from real experience: growing up in a low-income household in Manchester, his own family relied on free school meals and breakfast clubs.Today, a similar hand-to-mouth existence is being lived by millions of children across the country. And, in recent months, its been compounded by the coronavirus outbreak.Despite the Governments excellent furlough scheme, , Brits have lost their jobs during lockdown, with unemployment now set to hit the three million mark.As Rashford rightly observes, many families are living on a knes edge, gripped with fear over how they will pay their bills, cover their rent or even put food on the table.This is proven by new data from The Food Foundation, showing that food insecurity in households with children has nearly DOUBLED since the pandemic began.The research also reveals more than , youngsters have been forced to skip meals during lockdown because their family couldn’t access sufficient food.As Chair of the Commons Education Committee, I was delighted when, earlier this year, the Government extended its free school meals scheme for the Easter and May half-term holidays.Yet, like many, I believed its decision to halt the programme for the summer break was wrong.In my view, this was for three key reasons:Firstly, the vouchers have been a leline for many poverty-stricken families during the Covid lockdown. With further worrying and uncertain weeks ahead, these families need consistency.Secondly, and closely linked, is that millions of parents are struggling financially at the moment - something that may be exacerbated in August, when furlough contributions change.Feeding their kids over the summer will push their already stretched budgets to breaking point. Yet these youngsters desperately need, and deserve, nutritional meals.Thirdly, around three million children are at risk of holiday hunger every year .Extending the scheme was simply the right thing to do.It was also relatively easy: yes, its coming out of a £ million Covid Summer Food Fund, but unlike other schemes, it isnt bureaucratic and its understood by parents across England.It also goes to those who need it the most.Studies have shown that food poverty doesnt just impact on childrens health: malnourished kids are less likely to perform as well in the classroom as their better-off peers.This can shape the course of their adult le.England is already facing an educational Ice Ageschools cant open in September - by which point, children will have been out of education for six months.Despite parents home-schooling efforts,  per cent of teachers in the countrys most deprived areas have suggested their students are learning for less than one hour a day.And some , youngsters don’t have access to a computer or tablet at all.Its why Ive called for Alan Turing catch-up summer camps to be set up in school buildings, village halls and marquees - anywhere that can be used to educate our kids.Its also why, despite being a Tory MP, I publicly announced I would vote with Labour today and call on the Government to extend free school meals over the summer.To use a football analogy, it felt strange going to play for the opposite side. But like Rashford, I knew that impoverished families across the UK deserved more.Fortunately, Boris has seen sense, too.Amid this crisis, we need a bold vision from the PM about our childrens education: what are we going to do to get them learning again  How will we get them back to schools We need an exciting, confident agenda, because the next generation depends on it. With todays move, Boris has shown these families that, yes, we do mean business.As for Rashford, he has done as much -not more - for disadvantaged families than any politician. Hes brought a vital issue onto the national stage in a dignied way.Unlike virtue-signalling celebrities who fly on a plane from Los Angeles then go on about saving the environment, he has practised what he preaches.And in doing so, hes shown himself to be a nation icon on and off the pitch.To receive The Suns Coronavirus newsletterevery tea time, sign up here. Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: government parallel universe opinion
story: If they fancy studying one in slightly warmer climes, perhaps they should decamp to Britain.⚠️ Read our coronavirus live blog for the latest news  updatesAfter landing at Heathrow and filling out a form agreeing to a fortnight’s self-isolation, they could then hop on a train with, er, hundreds of other people and head in to the capital city, where, on a sunny day, they will pass ious parks that resemble Glastonbury Festival — a vast sprawl of people enjoying cheek-by-jowl picnics, washed down with alcohol purchased from a nearby supermarket.If they’re staying near London’s Oxford Street, they might observe the scrums at NikeTown and Primark, where thousands of desperate shoppers jostle for position, or they might chance upon " rel"noreferrer noopener"the warring factions of BLM and far-right protestors beating seven bells out of each other.And then, at around pm, they could tune in to the daily Government briefing where, flanked by two scientists, the PM or one of his ministers delivers grave warnings about the coronavirus, the possibility of a “second wave”, and how it is imperative we all continue to observe strict social-distancing measures.This, they justy regularly, is why the majority of workplaces are still shut, hundreds of thousands of children remain unschooled and the hospitality industry is on its knees.Parallel universe indeed.It’s often said that politicians live in “the Westminster bubble”, but it’s time they stepped outside of it and took a long hard look at what’s going on outside the confines of No.No one is listening any more. Well, the majority anyway.Be it scientist “Professor Lockdown” flouting his own advice, or Boris’s svengali Dominic Cummings bending the rules he helped make, the rot set in a couple of weeks ago and has now caused an undeniable fissure between the state and its initially compliant citizens.Yet, while thousands are blatantly breaking social distancing rules at parks, protests and shopping areas, many of them are still being furloughed — at vast taxpayer expense — to “stay home” from work.Whereas common sense dictates that being in an office that’s been health and safety-ed to the nth degree is a far more protected environment than any of the above.And what about schools  The majority of learning for GCSEs and A levels takes place in years  and  respectively, yet government plans for the " rel"noreferrer noopener"reopening of secondary schools remain “unclear”, with some reports saying they might not evenin September.Meaning that — on top of GCSEs and A levels being cancelled this year — hundreds of thousands of pupils will be in no position to take them next year either.If teenagers can gather in large, cheek-by-jowl groups at their local park, then surely ing to school isn’t beyond the pale  It might even be safer.As for the hospitality industry, well, not only is the two-metre rule killing it but pubs, in particular, face the galling reality of remaining closed while their beer gardens are used by hordes of people who’ve bought booze at the local supermarket.Enough already. Time, surely, for the Government to open its eyes to what’s happening around the country and exercise some common sense.Of course those who are vulnerable should continue to take as many protective measures as they wish, including remaining furloughed or off schoolnecessary.But the majority should nowto work or schooland start to get Britain back on its feet, both economically and psychologically.SCIENTISTS say that intelligent le could exist on as many as  planets in our galaxy.But they reckon aliens won’t visit Earth because of the distance.The two-week quarantine rules won’t help either.HOLLYWOOD actress Sharon Stone has revealed she was struck by lightening while doing the ironing.What a terrible shock.No, not the estimated billion volts that propelled Sharon across the kitchen, silly.The fact that a movie star was doing her own housework.TATLER magazine’s " rel"noreferrer noopener"controversial article on The Duchess of Cambridge proved that snobbery is still alive and kicking in certain sections of the British “upper” classes.Dredging up the age-old “doors to manual” jibe at Kate’s mother Carole, a former member of cabin crew, it also resurrected ancient, alleged whisperings among chinless wonders of her being “NQOCD” – not quite our class, darling.This week, Rosalind Mann died, after a -year career taking photos of posh “girls in pearls” for Country Le magazine.When asked the criteria for posing, she replied: “We never featured anyone whose house had a number.”There’s snobbery in the US too, but it’s largely centred around money, rather than class.In the compellingly vacuous Netflix series Selling Sunset, about a high-end estate agency in Hollywood, the buzz phrase is: “Millionaires have views, billionaires have compounds.”Sadly, I have neither.IN the next James Bond movie, No Time To Die, it’s reported that the legendary spy has a young daughter with Lea Seydoux’s character.Could this see those famous blue trunks being replaced by a papoose It’s tricky waters for Bond fans, with  per cent telling a recent poll that they think it’s a mistake to make the famous philanderer a family man.I’ll reserve judgment until the film is released, but suffice to say, tackling villains such as Le Chfre, Blofeld and Raoul Silva is child’s play compared to dealing with a toddler in meltdown.A PUNTER has placed a bet on Newsnight presenter Emily Maitlis becoming PM by the end of .A spokesman for bookmaker Coral said: “The bet took us by surprise but someone’s convinced Maitlis could be the perfect match for No!”Presumably they’re not taking bets on which party she’d stand for as that would be too obvious.RICKY Gervais says that wherever he is in the world, he always frequents Italian restaurants because: “I know it’s going to be good and the same.”We have a similar issue at Moore Towers where – whether we’re at a Greek, French, Chinese, Italian or Japanese restaurant – the Bloke will spend aeons studying the ious culinary delights on offer before ordering “steak and chips” pretty much every time.THE stylist and “best friend” to Meghan Markle, Jessica Mulroney, is embroiled in a race row after appearing to threaten the livelihood of black lestyle blogger Sasha Exeter.Jessica, who has apologised, has now been dropped from regular TV slots and, while the pair have reportedly spoken in private, the Duchess of Sussex has yet to support her friend publicly.Something tells me that, aside from saying: “I need to do better” regarding race and injustice in society, Jessica is about to learn another valuable lesson.Hard times will always reveal true friends.CLOTHING website Missguided has been heavily criticised by shoppers after using slim models to market its plus-range of clothes in sizes  to .One said: “This screams, ‘we want to profit from plus-sized iniduals without representing or supporting them in any way’.” Very true.Equally, those ads for accessible baths showers targeted at the elderly but featuring a woman in her forties with the agility of a mountain goat.GOT a story  RING The Sun on    or WHATSAPP on  or EMAIL exclusive@the-sunOur journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion title: foreign aid money spent wisely
story: Having a department specically for “international development” might sound virtuous, but it makes no sense.The Foreign Office, which is in charge of building relationships with foreign countries, is perfectly placed to spend our aid money where it counts. If it had been in charge all along, our whopping aid budget would most likely have been used to fund valuable projects in fast-developing African countries — natural allies for Britain post Brexit.Thanks to the rudderless Department for International Development, it’s been squandered on things like upgrading roads in India — an enormously rich country with a fleet of new warships and a space programme to boot. The Sun is all for helping the genuinely needy. But given this country is facing its worst recession in decades, now is hardly the moment to be sinking taxpayer cash into overseas vanity projects with no possible benefit for Brits. If Boris is determined to stick to David Cameron’s pledge to splash . per cent of GDP on foreign aid, then let’s thank our lucky stars it will now be spent wisely.THREE cheers for Marcus Rashford, a magnicent role model who yesterday won his campaign to make sure Britain’s poorest kids get one square meal a day over the summer. We know it will have been tough for the PM to swallow his pride and U-turn. But it was the right thing to do:  parents struggling to feed their children need all the help they can get right now. And £million — the cost of extending free school meal vouchers during the holidays — is a drop in the ocean when you consider the overall cost of lockdown.We like Rashford’s style, too. How refreshing to see a celebrity using his fame to articulate a powerful argument with such authenticity. NEW unemployment figures make for grim reading. The number of people claiming  jobless benefits more than doubled to hit .million in May — the  highest level since . And because the furlough scheme is masking the true extent of the crisis, we fear the worst is yet to come. Scientists are trained to think about public health  in the narrowest sense. So their instincts tell them to keep Britain in lockdown for as long as possible. But elected politicians know that  poverty and  mass unemployment kill just as surely as the virus. It’s time they showed some leadership and started easing restrictions in earnest. Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: couple dream home party bedsit surrey
story: Matt and Hannah Graydon claim they suffered from years of loud partying, drunken sessions and anti-social behaviour from the bedsit next door.The public relations professional couple bought the four-bed semi detached home in rural South Nutfield, Surrey in January .They claimed they were unable to sleep, forced to shield their kids ears from bad language and sometimes unable to use their garden, as tenant after tenant moved in and out of the bedsits.The couple sued their homes former owners Mark and Lisa Crook for £, claiming the sellers had deliberately withheld information about the noise from next door in order to induce a sale.Mr and Mrs Graydon said the couple must have been aware of anti-social behaviour next door and should have told them when they asked about their prospective neighbours.However, Judge Nigel Gerald threw out their case after a two-day trial - leaving them to pick up the bill that is expected to reach five figures. The court heard that before the Graydons bought the home, the adjoining house had been converted so that up to seven rooms were rented inidually as bedsits to tenants.Mr Graydon, , who runs his own PR and communications company, told the judge police attended the bedsit very frequently and they had to put up with the noise of loud partying and people coming and going at all hours.Mrs Graydon, who is a communications director for Caterham School, claimed groups would gather outside the house for drunken sessions - which sometimes ended in violence and police cars or ambulances turning up.She said at times her family felt unsafe using their own back garden because of the type of noise coming from the garden of the next door property.Mr and Mrs Graydon claimed the former owners made adeliberate omission about the neighbouring property.Barrister Kwabena Owusu, representing Mr and Mrs Cook, argued it was a case of having a dferent experience compared to the current owners.He told the judge: Their case is that they werent signicantly disturbed by noise.Mr and Mrs Crook had no such experience .They have been perfectly sincere in the answers they have given the court and gave you at the time.Mr Owusu added that in the  years the couple lived at the property they never had a reason to call the police because of next door.The Graydons accepted that the current occupants are quieter than some of the previous tenants.They claimed damaged for the alleged misrepresentation and said their house was actually worth £, less than what they boughtor.The judge rejected the Graydons claim and he said he was not convinced that Mr and Mrs Crook had the same experience when they lived in the house.The Graydons now face a court bill which is expected to run well into five figures.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: boris hails australia uk trade talks penguins marmite
story: The PM said the two countries already shared so much and they would thrash out a deal so Brits could get their hands on more Australian speciality foods including Tim Tams and vegemite.In a video posted to Twitter, Mr Johnson brandished a family-size pack of the Australian chocolate biscuits Tim Tams, and asked: How long can the British people be deprived of the opportunity to have Arnotts Tim Tams at a reasonable price He said: Im absolutely thrilled today to be inaugurating the UK-Australia, Australia-UK free trade agreement talks. Its quite extraordinary to think of all the things we trade with each other already even without a free trade deal.We import colossal quantities of absolutely delicious Australian wine, we export all kinds of things including - I was amazed to discover boomerangs made in the UK exported to Australia. The PM said he envisaged a world where Brits send Aussies marmite and penguins in exchange for them sending Vegemite and Tim Tams. He added the deal wasnt all about Australian food and wine, but it would include agreements on financial services and all other sectors of the economy. In a reciprocal twitter video from Aussie PM Scott Morrison, he said he was hopeful a deal could be done as soon as the end of next year. He said: For a large part of our economic history the UK was Australias largest trading partner and the UK remains today one of Australias most important investment partners.As we build back from the impact of COVID- we have a wonderful opportunity to supercharge our economic relationship.It will mean more jobs, more growth, more prosperity in both our countries, and more opportunities for Australians and UK citizens to live and work in each others countries. Australian High Commissioner to the UK George Brandis tweeted that Britain needed to ditch the  per cent tarrf tax on Tim Tams as part of the free trade deal. The PM has pledged to make free trade deals with countries across the world - including Australia and the US - as part of his plan to boost the UK economy after the end of the transition period on December . After stalled trade talks with the EU, Mr Johnson said last week the two parties needed to put a tiger in the tank and forced them to agree an intensied program of negotiations. title: stars call for marcus rashford to be knighted after free school meals victory
story: Rashford, , has been praised for his efforts in convincing the Government to provide £ a week meal vouchers for poor kids in the UK during the summer holidays.After increased pressure from Tory MPs and celebrities, the Government revealed it would fund the scheme after all, despite initially saying it would not carry on over the summer.The Manchester United aces efforts towards keeping the free meals scheme going have prompted calls for him to receive a knighthood.Ex-England cricketer Kevin Pietersen praised the Premier League star on Twitter, calling him “Sir Marcus Rashford” while former Sunderland player Michael Gray tweeted “SIR @MarcusRashford”.Radio presenter Paul Ross added: “I never remember being hungry as a kid but I was a free school dinner kid - as were  of the  of us - and it helped with the Ross household budget. That and the Family Allowance were le savers. Arise Sir M!”The hashtag #SirMarcusRashford was trending on Twitter on Wednesday as fans heaped praise on the young striker.What an inspiration Marcus Rashford is. His campaigning could save lives... Rashford deserves a knighthood, one fan wrote.Personally think you should receive a knighthood. The amount of children you have helped and saved from being hungry throughout the day are in the hundreds of thousands, another supporter posted.If Rashford is knighted it would make him one of the youngest people ever to receive the honour - seven years younger than tennis champion Sir Andy Murray was when he was given a knighthood.He would join other Manchester United legends including managers Sir Matt Busby and Sir Alex Ferguson and player Sir Bobby Charlton. Rashfords odds of receiving a knighthood plummeted after his charity work during the Covid- pandemic, dropping to  .In a statement addressed to all MPs, Rashford thanked them for giving families one less thing to worry about after the u-turn.This was never about me or you, this was never about politics, this was a cry out for help from vulnerable parents all over the country and I simply provided a  for their voices to be heard, he wrote in the statement shared on social media.I stand proud today knowing that we have listened, and we have done what is right.There is still a long way to go but I am thankful to you all that we have given these families just one less thing to worry about tonight.The wellbeing of our children should ALWAYS be a priority.The PMs spokesperson said yesterday that the Government would run a Covid food fund throughout the summer.He said: “The PM welcomed Marcus Rashford’s contribution to the debate around poverty and I said he would be responding as soon as possible.Owing to the coronavirus pandemic, the PM fully understands that children and parents face an entirely unprecedented situation over the summer.To to reflect this, we will be providing a Covid summer food fund.This will provide food vouchers covering the six week holiday period.This was a specic measure to reflect the unique circumstances of the pandemic.The scheme will not continue beyond the summer and those eligible will be those who already qualy for free school meals.”Ministers have said they will continue with plans to put an additional £million of money into local authorities to help those who cant afford basic essentials.The dramatic u-turn followed England star Rashford penning a heartfelt open letter to the government - urging them to reverse their decision.He wrote: “The Government has taken a ‘whatever it takes’ approach to the economy - I’m asking you today to extend that same thinking to protecting all vulnerable children across England.“I encourage you to hear their pleas and find your humanity.”Rashford, who has raised £ million to boost food distribution with the charity FareShare, revealed how he used food banks and received free meals during his childhood in Manchester.The forward wrote: “We relied on breakfast clubs, free school meals, and the kind actions of neighbours and coaches.“Food banks and soup kitchens were not alien to us - I recall very clearly our visits to Northern Moor to collect our Christmas dinners every year.“As a black man from a low-income family in Manchester, I could have been just another statistic.Make the u-turn and make protecting the lives of some of our most vulnerable a top priority.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: germans love brit free majorca quiet holiday resort coronavirus
story: Spain " href"https:www.thesun travel  british-tourists-spain " target"_blank" rel"noreferrer noopener"this week started welcoming the Germans as its first foreign holidaymakers since the lockdown began in March.The visitors started arriving in Majorca on Monday as part of a trial scheme to test new coronavirus measures before the more of the country is opened up to visitors from other nations.The trial will see over , Germans visit the island over the next two weeks – while Brits remain on the banned list.And those who have landed so far have said they are loving it.Wolfgang, , who is retired, and Christiane Gmelch, , a bank manager, arrived on Monday from Wurzburg in their first ever trip to the island and are staying in Playa de Palma.He told Sun Online: The security measures are excellent. In the hotel you have to wear the masks.In the restaurant you have to wear gloves and when you go into the hotel, restaurant or bars they take your temperature.  They have hand sanitiser in the toilets, rooms, restaurant and elevator.We are used to having to do the same in Germany and its not a big problem for us. We know the rules and do exactly the same here.The only thing is its a little bit dficult to talk to other tourists on the next table because of the social distancing.We were expecting many more people, but its nice for us, there are so few.Baibel and Matthias Drews who have been going to Majorca for the past  years arrived from Emsdetten on Monday for a weeks holiday in Playa de Palma.Baibel, a civil servant, said: The staff in the hotel take your temperature when you arrive, then at breakfast and again in the evening.If you go out of the hotel they will also take it again. When we came before there were many more people on the beach, but not so many now.“Supposedly, more cafes and bars are meant to open up tomorrow. story: At least one staff member at the  Sisters Food Group site in Anglesey, North Wales is being treated in hospital and  others have tested positive.The plant processes chicken for fast food chain KFC and other major retailers.Paddy McNaught, regional officer for Unite the Union, described it as a major outbreak after a quarter of the plants  workers are self-isolating.He added: The company are taking this seriously.Our stewards are working with the company on site to put protective measures in place.But theres no doubt that people are very frightened. title: gyms leisure centres five aside july
story: Oliver Dowden said that grassroots sport would be part of the next stage of the nations coronavirus recovery in the coming weeks.Gym bunnies will be able to get back to their weights and yoga classes soon, and football fans allowed a kickabout with friends, Mr Dowden said. title: cecil rhodes statue oxford black lives matter
story: The famous college made the recommendation after an outcry over his links with Britain’s colonial past by Black Lives Matter protesters.⚠️ Click here for the latest news on Black Lives MatterThe Rhodes Must Fall Oxford campaign group had called for the image of the controversial mining magnate and empire builder to be removed from Oriel College, arguing the university has failed to address its institutional racism.Hundreds of protesters had gathered in front of the Rhodes statue on the High Street in Oxford recently as part of the Black Lives Matter movement.Carole Souter, the current master of St Cross College and former chief executive of the National Lottery Heritage Fund, will chair an independent commission into the issue.Announcing it was launching an independent public inquiry into the key issues surrounding the statue, a statement by the College said: “The Governing Body of Oriel College has today voted to launch an independent Commission of Inquiry into the key issues surrounding the Rhodes statue.“They also expressed their wish to remove the statue of Cecil Rhodes and the King Edward Street Plaque.This is what they intend to convey to the Independent Commission of Inquiry.Rhodes was one of the era most famous imperialists, with Rhodesia - now Zimbabwe and Zambia - named after him.  Born in Bishops Stortford in , he was a sickly child beforeheading to Africa aged .He grew cotton before moving into diamond mining, founding the De Beers firm.As Prime Minister of the Cape Colony from  to , his government restricted the rights of black Africans by setting financial qualications for voting.He attended Oriel College in . On his death in  the Rhodes Scholarship was set up to help non-British students study at Oxford. Rhodes Scholars include Bill Clinton and three former Australian PMs.Students campaigned to have the figure of Victorian empire builder torn down in  over claims he was a racist. But Oriel College decided to keep it following threats from wealthy donors to withdraw £million in funding. “Both of these decisions were reached after a thoughtful period of debate and reflection, and with the full awareness of the impact these decisions are likely to have in Britain and around the world.The commission will deal with the issue of the Rhodes legacy and how to improve access and attendance of BAME undergraduate, graduate students and faculty, together with a review of how the colleges st-century commitment to ersity can sit more easily with its past.An open letter from campaigners to the universitys vice-chancellor claimed the institution has only made inconsequential inroads into tackling the material legacy of imperialism, adding it is not enough.Thousands of people signed two petitions calling for the statue of colonialist Rhodes at Oriel College to be taken down.A student at Oriel in his youth, Rhodes left the college money and also endowed the Rhodes Scholarships, which have allowed more than , students from countries around the world, including former US President Bill Clinton, to study at Oxford.The mining magnate was a central figure in Britains colonial project in southern Africa, giving his name to Rhodesia, present-day Zimbabwe, and founding the De Beers diamond empire.It comes amid a wider decolonise movement sweeping universities across the world in recent years.The Rhodes Must Fall movement was established in  at Cape Town University, and later spread to Oxford, where students demanded the statue of Rhodes was removed from Oriel College.In , Oriel College decided to keep the statue following threats from wealthy donors to withdraw £million in funding.Elsewhere today work started in central London to remove the metal boards covering Sir Winston Churchills statue ahead of the French presidents visit to London tomorrow.Sir Winstons statue, along with those of Nelson Mandela and Gandhi, was boarded up on June , after it was defaced with graffiti saying he was a racist during a Black Lives Matter demonstration.The news comes after a statue of th century slave trader Edward Colston was pulled down and dumped into Bristol Harbour during a recent Black Lives Matter protest.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: boris must help new tories in north
story: The Manchester United and England striker forced the Government into a sudden U-turn.As a result, this summer some .million of the UK’s poorest kids will be getting free school meal vouchers.Rashford had been campaigning on the issue and wrote a letter to the Prime Minister.Good for him. The Government’s decision not to pay for the vouchers was mean-spirited and cheap.But you do wonder about a government which decides upon a policy — and then changes it as soon as a top footballer opens his mouth.Next week, Michael Gove decides to extend trade negotiations with the EU after an intervention by Harry Kane. And lockdown is lted completely when Kyle Walker says he wants to go to another house party.Still, Rashford was right and deserves credit. And he’s right, too, that the Government could go further in helping those of us who live in poverty. The pandemic has thrown the Government off course.It was bound to. But Boris and Co must remember why they were elected last December. They got a huge mandate from our country’s very poorest regions. The areas that usually support the Labour Party.That was partly because of Brexit, of course. And partly because the then Labour leader, Jeremy Corbyn , was about as effective as a recently gassed badger.But it was also because Boris promised those former Labour heartlands what they wanted to hear.A closing of the ide between rich and poor, and between London and the rest of the country.Jobs, investment in new industries and transport infrastructure.He might think we’ve all forgotten. But we haven’t. The latest poll shows Labour only five points behind the Conservatives.The honeymoon is over.Boris could begin by increasing the minimum wage for people aged  and over. It is low wages, far more than unemployment, which is keeping people mired in poverty.It wouldn’t cost the Government very much at all. It would also provide a much-needed boost to the economy.An increase in free childcare from  hours per week to  hours would also enable those struggling to make ends meet to get out of the house and work for longer.Shortly after last December’s election, Boris turned up in the North East to give his thanks.He once again promised that the region would be rejuvenated.There’s been good news on some fronts — the Nissan plant at Sunderland, for example, won out over its rival in Barcelona. It will stay open, despite the loss of  jobs.But more needs to be done to attract industry to the North and the Midlands.So far as I can see, the Government has done nothing. OK, it’s had a few problems on its hands.But when this pandemic has passed, the Government will need to intervene to help our economy — the private sector alone cannot do it.And the place to start is away from London — in the places where the new breed of Tory voter lives.Marcus Rashford’s intervention was timely and needed. This Government needs to know the poor are watching and waiting. Waiting for action, waiting for the promises of last year to be delivered.THERE is a stupidity about the woke crowd, trying to ban everything, which defies belief.An old episode of Fawlty Towers was pulled. Because it had some disturbing and potentially offensive racial material in it.But as the star of it, John Cleese, tried patiently to explain – it was SATIRE.The character of Basil Fawlty was the subject of the humour. He was mocked for his idiocies. That’s why we laughed.The episode has now been reinstated – but the moron caravan has already moved on. Now they’ve got it in for Mahatma Gandhi. Racist! The bloke who fought for India’s liberation from British colonialism.Was he a racist  Yes, without much doubt. He took a pretty jaundiced view towards Africans. But the good he did easily outweighs the bad.And believe me, there isn’t a single person born before  who didn’t possess views which today’s society would consider offensive. Regarding race, or gender, or homosexuality. Not one.Why can these people not understand that the past was dferent  And that we judge its heroes in a dferent light There was a really nasty battle between the two sides, with many dead – the first time since .China continues to bully its neighbours and oppress its own people.In this battle, I know whose side I’m on.THE Government has not done much right recently.But at least Boris and Co are binning the Department for International Development.It is to be stripped of its status and merged with the Foreign Office.With any luck, this will mean we will not be giving away any more hard-earned taxpayers’ money to countries like India, which has its own space programme so is clearly not short of a bob or two.Or China – a nasty, totalitarian state and the second richest country in the world.In the last round of spending, we actually bunged money into a programme to help Chinese people improve their diets.Nope, not kidding.I wonderit mentioned anything about it maybe not being a great idea to eat bats Various studies have suggested these donations are worthless and often counter-productive.I think, right now, we need to spend money at home, no SCIENTISTS from Japan have predicted that within  years we will be able to understand what animals are thinking. We will be communicating with them.Uh-oh. Not sure that’s good. Imagine a chat with a wasp . . .“Hi, Mr Wasp. What you doing ”“I’m crawling up your window. What’s it to you  And it’s Ms Wasp, as it happens. I’ve transitioned. So don’t misgender me. Now, p*** off before I sting you on the neck.”Worse with cats. “LOVE you  WTF, I’ve never even liked you. You’re mugs, humans. Just put the food out and give me a warm place to sleep and I’ll purr for a bit to keep you happy. Now, excuse me. I’m going to sleep on the roof of the shed for six hours.”But I might start watching it now as the cast all seem to hate each other.The soap has been torn apart by rows over the Black Lives Matter debate.Lysette Anthony has taken loads of flack and her co-star Rachel Adedeji has described her as “actual trash”.Hmm . . . somehow I suspect the show will not be anywhere near as interesting as the row.NOT everything about lockdown has been bad. Far from it.My we hasn’t been to TK Maxx for three months, for a start. There’s a mercy.And we’re not using cash. There’s little indication we will need to use cash ever again.Those people who aren’t on the breadline have saved money.And then there’s offices. Will we really go back to that awful daily commute, when the vast majority of jobs can, these days, be done at home  Just think how many homes we could createwe converted all those empty offices into flats.Offices were created because we needed a place to store paper files. Don’t really need that now, do we The Government should encourage firms to move to home-working, when – the stats suggest – employees are a lot more productive.IN France – a country almost as badly hit by Covid- as the UK – the schools will be reopening on Monday. By law, no arguments. Full curriculum.Over here, meanwhile, there are suggestions that some schools will not be opening until JANUARY and will not open properly for a year. Incredible.The Government needs to get a grip of this right now, as I argued last week.Call the bluff of the horrible trade unions and get our kids back to school. Or this will be the lost generation.GOT a story  RING The Sun on    or WHATSAPP on  or EMAIL exclusive@the-sunOur journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: meghan markle harry archewell trademark application rejected
story: The former royals didnt sign the applicaton, it was too vague and they didnt pay all the fees required.They reportedly delayed the launch of their organization after relocating to LA amid the pandemic.And Harry and Meghan have hit a stumbling block with the United States Patent and Trademark Office after submitting their application on March .Paperwork seen by The Sun shows it was filed by Cobblestone Lane LLC, which is registered in Delaware but linked to the Beverly Hills offices of a Hollywood power lawyer, who has worked for Meghan for years.As reported, Meghan and Harry are looking into creating a non-profit organization which offers emotional support groups, a multimedia educational empire, and a well-being website, similar to the former actresss deleted blog, The Tig.An examiner was assigned to review their application on May  and they have since been sent an Irregularity Notice by the USPTO addressing a catalog of errors, including the vague nature of the proposed charitable work, according to documents.The Notice features a number of changes which need to be made by the couples attorney, Marjorie Witter Norman, by August  - otherwise the application will become abandoned.The International Bureau considers the list of goods and or services listed for the non-profit as being too vague for the purposes of classication.The Notice reads: The wording providing a website featuring content relating to philanthropy, monetary giving, volunteer and career opportunities in International Class  is also indefinite and over broad, and must be claried to specy the nature of the content provided.The Notice also states that Meghan and Harry need to pay some additional fees to process their application.A Non-Final Action was sent on June , and their trademark can be held without being active until the required amendments are filed.In a final blunder, the examiner claims in the Non-Final Office Action: The application was unsigned, resulting in the application not being properly veried.The Sun understands even the most diligently drafted trademark application may be initially rejected by the USPTO, with one in five failing their first examination.Meghan and Harry, who are currently holed up at Tyler Perrys million LA mansion, confirmed plans for their charity in April and said they look forward to getting back to work after stepping down from royal le in January and ditching their Sussex Royal brand.We connected to this concept for the charitable organization we hoped to build one day, and it became the inspiration for our sons name, they told The Daily . To do something of meaning, to do something that matters.Archewell is a name that combines an ancient word for strength and action, and another that evokes the deep resources we each must draw upon.They added: We look forward to launching Archewell when the time is right.The non-profit aims to offer classes, lectures, seminars, conferences, workshops, and retreats on a iety of topics, run a mentoring scheme, or conduct and host events and exhibitions for cultural, sporting, health, mental health and entertainment purposes, as well as the potential to self-publish articles, magazines, books, music, podcasts, television shows, and computer software.According to reports this week, they have delayed their plans until at least next year, as they focus their efforts on the Black Lives Matter movement and fighting COVID-.Describing how a public launch is now off the cards, a source told the Daily : Whats absolutely clear is that they want to get it right and theres no point in rushing.They are settling into a new le, a new era. This is about getting it right and making sure they are able to make the dference they want to make.The Sun has reached out to Meghan and Harrys rep and trademark attorney for comment.Do you have a story for The US Sun team Email us at exclusive@the-sun or call   .Like us on Facebook at www.facebook TheSunUS and follow us from our main Twitter account at @TheSunUS.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: britain bottom world league table handling coronavirus pandemic
story: The analysis awarded a score out of four to  OECD countries based on their testing programmes, healthcare, and death tolls. With a score of ., the UK was level with Spain and Italy, at one point the global epicentre of the crisis. Belgium came in last with a score of .. Countries that performed well included Australia, Denmark, Iceland, Israel, and Norway, all of which scored over .. New Zealand received the best rating with ., while Germany and Austria placed joint second with ..Sweden, which never imposed a full lockdown, instead using a herd immunity strategy similar to that initially pursued by the UK, scored just ..The analysis was done by the Economists Intelligence Unit. Specic measures used included the number of tests carried out per million people, the number of cancer-related surgeries cancelled, and excess deaths per million people. Preexisting risk factors such as levels of obesity, the number of people aged above , and the number of international arrivals were also taken into account. The most signicant reason for the UKs low score was its levels of excess deaths. The report singled out the countrys low levels of testing and a controversial decision to stop contact tracing in March as contributing factors. It added that the UKs position as an international travel hub, and the number of people passing through airports like Heathrow, could have played a part. The government has also been criticised for delaying the decision to lockdown until after the country was already seeing signicant spread of the virus. The UK has so far seen , deaths from the pandemic, signicantly more than any other country with a comparable population. Only Brazil and the US, whose populations are three and five times that of the UK respectively, have seen more deaths.In spite of its high death toll, the US performed well in the rankings once its initial risk factors were taken into account. In contrast to Britain, other poorly-performing countries like Spain and Italy were hit early on in the pandemic and had little time to prepare, the report said. It also said that the UKs centralised healthcare system meant the government had a wealth of public health data that should have aided its response.   Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: pensioner finds squatter in motorhome
story: The owner found clothes hanging up, plus a duvet, pillow and booze in the ft by ft luggage compartment.She fears the mystery camper may have been living on her driveway for weeks.But the OAP, known only as Angela, says authorities showed little interest when she raised the alarm last week.Instead, she was told to slap a “Police Aware” notice on the belongings in the hope it stopped them ing.She said: “I was gobsmacked. They could have been there for days or weeks. I was shaking.”Angela said she found a Hugo Boss shirt hanging up, along with a pair of Levis, while some Calvin Klein pants were by the door.She added: “There was also what appeared to be a Swedish brand of cider on a shelf, a brown apple core and a chocolate biscuit. Someone had obviously set up home in there and made themselves very cosy.“It is a mystery because none of my neighbours saw anyone coming or going.“It is actually quite a disturbing incident and I have been left pretty shaken up by it, and feeling a little bit frightened.”Angela, of Hollesley, Suffolk. said the compartment was empty when she last used her £, camper for a trip to northern France last June.She said cops told her to “bag everything up and put it at the end of the driveway with a note”. But it was not collected.Suffolk Police confirmed cops were called about “belongings”. A spokesman said: “At this time, there will be no further police enquiries.”GOT a story  RING The Sun on    or WHATSAPP on  or EMAIL exclusive@the-sunOur journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: teens say theyve learned nothing in lockdown
story: BEFORE lockdown, Finn Clyde was always up at am for school and was in the top sets of his classes.But since schools closed in March, the -year-old has turned his back on learning and spends all day playing on his Xbox in his room. Finn, of Carmarthen, South West Wales, says: “I don’t feel motivated to do work because I don’t always understand it.“I don’t find it fun like it is at school and I’d rather socialise online with my friends. It’s just easier than trying to do the school work.“It’s a way of escaping from everything.“I’m worried the teachers will be disappointed in me because I haven’t done enough work.“I’m worried I’ll fall behind and have to resit the year when all my friends go on.”And he is not alone. A study by University College London revealed that two million children have done barely any schoolwork at home.Since March, around  per cent of pupils have done none, or less than an hour, a day. And just  per cent put in more than four hours a day.Finn’s mum Kerrie, , a former secondary school teacher, admits she only ever sees her son at meal times.The single mum, who also has daughters Imogen, , and six-year-old Elodie, has found it hard to juggle home-schooling with working full-time as a social worker.She says: “When lockdown started I thought I’d be able to manage, especially because I used to be a teacher.“I was really motivated and ordered lots of stuff on Amazon to help. I think because the kids could see I was motivated it rubbed off on them.“But as time has gone on it’s become more dficult and challenging. I can’t give  per cent to my job and  per cent to teaching my kids. It’s just not possible.”Now Finn usually gets up around .am, has breakfast then switches on his games console — and stays up until midnight.Kerrie says: “I tried to get Finn to do schoolwork. With not enough computers for me and the kids to work, I even set written work for him.“But I couldn’t make him do it, no matter how much I encouraged him.” As we report today, more than , child health experts have signed an open letter to Boris Johnson demanding the Government publishes a clear plan to get all youngsters back to school as soon as possible or “risk scarring the le chances of a generation of young people”.The letter, organised by the Royal College of Paediatrics and Child Health, warns children are “suffering enormously” from a lack of access to exercise, vaccinations and mental health support.m have done under an hour’s work a day, experts warn PM it will ‘scar a generation’This is par­ti­cu­larly concern­ing for Clare Cashion, , when it comes to -year-old daughter Libby.Clare, a civil servant from Worcester, who is also mum to Ollie, , Lochlan, four, and two-year-old Cullann, says: “Libby has gone from being a  hardworking student to a changed character, so I do worry about her wellbeing.”Libby now stays awake until am and usually gets up at about lunchtime. Instead of doing schoolwork, she spends most of her time talking to friends on social media.She says: “At first we didn’t know what we were supposed to be doing, and because there wasn’t proper work or anyone to check your work and because you can’t just ask questions, I didn’t want to do it.“When I did do it, I didn’t get any feedback, and then my friends would tell me they hadn’t bothered, so I just thought, ‘What’s the point ’.“I’m a huge worrier and I am concerned about falling behind, but I’d rather stay up and talk to friends on my phone. That’s when everyone is online.“Mum tries to make me do more schoolwork but it doesn’t work. There just doesn’t seem much point at the moment. “I’d just like to go back to school.”In a report last month, government advisory body Sage warned lockdown had caused a “shock” to kids that will last the rest of their lives and affect work opportunities.The report also confirmed the risk of children catching coronavirus was “much lower” than adults.Yesterday, MPs on the Education Select Committee accused teaching unions of running a “disgraceful political campaign” to keep classrooms closed by “cherry picking” evidence to make parents fear schools are “death traps”.Chairman Robert Halfon asked: “Can you explain why parents and children can have access to Primark over the coming weeks and months but not to schools ”For Libby and Clare, it will be a big relief when schools can reopen. Clare says: “School has now started online lessons, so one week they’ll be live, and  Libby has taken part in some, but the following week it’s just emails and sometimes they have to cancel.“I think Libby struggles with not knowing exactly what’s expected.”Finn is just as desperate to get back in the classroom.He said: “I really want to go back to school because it’s a lot easier to learn in a classroom with a teacher explaining the work, and I miss my independence.“I’ve found it really dficult being at home this long.”To receive The Sun’s Coronavirus newsletterevery tea time, sign up here.To follow us on Facebook, simply ‘Like’ our Coronavirus page.Get Britain’s best-selling newspaper delivered to your smartphone or tablet each day – find out more.GOT a story  RING The Sun on    or WHATSAPP on  or EMAIL exclusive@the-sunOur journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: che guevara face tree moss bromley
story: Walker Gerald Russell thought the bark had been vandalised at first.Then he clocked the Marxist rebel’s outline — complete with stubble and trademark cap — staring back from a clump of dark moss.Gerald, , said: “I thought it was very artistic but annoyed someone would deface a tree. Several walks later I realised it was actually moss.“Che Guea was my first impression. I didn’t know much about him until I googled him, although I’ve seen his picture many times over the years.”Argentine Guea helped Castro’s communists win in Cuba in the s.He was later captured by US-backed Bolivian forces and executed at the age of  in .The image of a beret-clad Guea in Havana has been printed on millions of t-shirts and posters, making him a symbol of the revolutionary spirit.The woods in Bromley, South London, are near the home of Nigel Farage.Mr Russell said you can also see a woman’s head and chest. title: shutdown wrecking childrens education
story: Mary Bousted, Corbynite boss of the National Education Union, apparently relished telling MPs yesterday that schools might have to stay shut into October. That is unthinkable.Top children’s doctors say the closures are doing catastrophic damage. Boris Johnson has made clear he wants schools open. Where is Sir Keir Starmer Labour’s leader knows they are safe to reopen. He has sent his own children to school throughout lockdown. But he remains mute, in fear of his MPs and the unions. His panicky confusion when put on the spot by the PM was telling.Labour’s Twitter addicts love the social media term “gaslighting”, where someone deliberately confuses an opponent so that they question their own sanity. Starmer’s MPs are trying to do the same thing to the entire nation.They, along with Labour councils and unions, have been the chief obstructions to restarting schools, having whipped up fear among teachers and parents in defiance of the scientic advice. One day scaremongering, the next denouncing the Tories for betraying kids.The reality is that Boris should now bin the -pupil class size limit and the crazy two-metre distancing edict. There is minimal evidence to support either.Then he must order schools to reopen.The shutdown is wrecking children’s education every day it grinds on.IT is vital for our economy and sanity that we can take a holiday from early July.So we urge the PM: Thrash out a deal with President Macron today, allowing free travel with France with no quarantine. Rapidly make similar “air bridge” deals with Spain, Portugal and Greece.Better still, replace the crippling, job-destroying absurdity of quarantine — its rules are too slack to work, anyway — with temperature checks at airports.Then get our hotels and B’n’Bs open for a tsunami of “staycations”.Do it now, before summer is gone and a vast number of tourism jobs with it.IT was fantastic to have the Prem back last night. And we salute all efforts toit to greater normality next season.But, we have to say, “digital health passports” sound like a recipe for turnstile chaos. And will they even be needed Yes, there could yet be a second wave. But imagine insteadby September daily Covid deaths are at or near zero.Imaginethere is no spike in cases triggered by the recent mass protests.The idea that major outdoor events should remain banned or subject to cumbersome health checks will look barking mad.GOT a story  RING The Sun on    or WHATSAPP on  or EMAIL exclusive@the-sunOur journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: green pus leg lamb roast
story: Amanda Wright Rima, from Sydney, Australia, was cooking a roast for the family when she noticed something strange with the meat shed bought.As she spotted the light green pus was seeping from the leg of lamb,she inspected it further by making an incision with her kne. As she pushed into the meat the fluid began pour from the hole.Horried by what she had seen, she filmed the gruesome discovery and posted it on Facebook.Cooked a roast for  minutes and went to put the veggies in and noticed something strange seeping out, she wrote. Needless to say we wont be having lamb roast again after this.Friends on Facebook suggested the liquid was pus from a cyst beneath the skin. One person wrote: Oh my God thats disgusting. If you didnt check you would of all been so sick.Another added: This is the grossest thing Ive ever seen Thats enough to turn you vegetarian, a third said. Bizarrely, this didnt shock some people, with users saying that the same incident had previously happened to them. Yuck, I hate when the meat or chicken has a tumour or cyst in it, have to chuck the whole lot out, another comment read. Another said: Looks like an abscess in the leg. Thats pus.A spokesperson for Coles, the supermarket Amanda had purchased the leg from: We have strict quality standards that all livestock partners must meet. Coles has already issued this customer a refund and apologised for the unpleasant experience. title: uncle bens logo black lives matter
story: “We recognise that now is the right time to evolve the Uncle Ben’s brand, including its visual brand identity, which we will do,” food giant Mars, the parent company, said in a statement.“Racism has no place in society. We stand in solidarity with the Black community, our Associates and our partners in the fight for social justice,” the statement added. Mars explained on its website that Uncle Ben is a fictional character whose name was first used in  as a reference to an African American Texan male rice farmer. The image of the African American who has come to persony the brand “was a beloved Chicago chef and waiter named Frank Brown,” the company said.While it is unclear what the exact changes or timing will be, Mars added that it is “evaluating all possibilities.”The move to rebrand Uncle Ben’s follows a similar announcement from Quaker Oats, which plans to change its Aunt Jemima pancake and syrup name and logo.The worlds first ready pancake mix features an African American woman named Aunt Jemima, who was originally dressed as a minstrel show performer.Kristin Kroepfl, vice president and chief marketing officer of Quaker Foods North America, revealed the changes in a press release.We recognise Aunt Jemimas origins are based on a racial stereotype, Kroepfl said.As we work to make progress toward racial equality through several initiatives, we also must take a hard look at our portfolio of brands and ensure they reflect our values and meet our consumers expectations.The Quaker Oats Company, a subsidiary of PepsiCo., purchased Aunt Jemima Mills Company in .PepsiCo, which merged with Quaker Oats  years ago, has not yet revealed what the new name or logo will be.Kroepfl added in the statement, obtained by Adweek: “We are starting by removing the image and changing the name.“We will continue the conversation by gathering erse perspectives from both our organisation and the Black community to further evolve the brand and make it one everyone can be proud to have in their pantry.”Corporations across the US are undertaking new measures to show their support for the African American community following the killing of George Floyd.Floyd died of asphyxiation from sustained pressure last month after white cop Derek Chauvin was filmed kneeling on his neck for almost nine minutes during an arrest.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: health chiefs review vitamin d coronavirus save lives
story: Studies have previously suggested that a deficiency of the vitamin makes a person more likely to die after contracting the virus. The UKs relatively low levels of sunshine and Brits diets mean vitamin D deficiency is a widespread problem in the country. An estimated one in five adults and one in six children dont get enough vitamin D - a problem that its feared could be being exacerbated by the lockdown. One study by Anglia Ruskin University found that European countries in which vitamin D deficiency is prevalent have seen elevated death tolls since the start of the pandemic. The National Institute for Health and Care Excellence, part of the Department of Health, has now announced a rapid evidence review looking at the trend, thereported. The results of the review are set to be published in the coming weeks. The Scientic Advisory Committee on Nutrition, which advises Public Health England and other government organisations on nutrition, will also complete a report. Heightened vulnerability caused by a lack of vitamin D could be part of the reason that both the elderly and certain ethnic minority groups have seen higher fatality rates from the virus.Melanin, the pigment that makes a persons skin darker, lowers the skins ability to produce vitamin D in response to sunlight exposure. The bodys ability to produce the vitamin also diminishes as a person gets older. In April, Public Health England advised Brits to begin taking vitamin D supplements to help maintain bone and muscle health during the lockdown.Earlier this month, the Scottish government also recommended that anyone from an ethnic group with darker skin should begin taking the supplement. Officials are said to be discussing whether the supplement could be prescribed in hospitals to help mitigate the impact of any second wave.Professor Adrian Martineau of Queen Mary University, currently leading a study into the vulnerability to coronavirus of people with dferent lestyles, told thethe benefits of vitamin D could be considerable. Vitamin D could almost be thought of as a designer drug for helping the body to handle viral respiratory infections, he said. Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: dad shocked to see couple romping in their car outside his window in broad daylight
story: Will Oliver, , was washing up in his kitchen when he noticed unusual movement in a red Ford Focus.The dad-of-two moved to take a closer look and spotted a man lying on the back seat of the hatchback with a woman energetically bouncing up and down on top of him.But instead of being shocked Will, of Basildon, Essex, bizarrely confessed it was in keeping with the area where he lives.He said: They werent exactly being discreet. But I wasnt that surprised, given where we live.They were parked up in an empty car park round the back of our block of flats, which doesnt really get used except for occasionally people going round there to have a splf.They were there for about half an hour, from around pm to .pm, before they drove off. I caught a glimpse of them but I didnt recognise them.I was only glancing at them for about  seconds - I have two young girls, aged six and two, so I had to make sure they werent going to look out the window.Will, who lives in a flats overlooking the saucy spott said he had never seen any doggers in his neighbourhood before he spied the pair on Monday.He said his lack of surprise was a general view on the area being a little run-down.He did not see the couple arrive but says when they finished they caught their breath before driving off together.GOT a story  RING The Sun on    or WHATSAPP on  or EMAIL exclusive@the-sunOur journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: government guidance two metre rule work
story: It gives employers wriggle room on operating the two-metre social distancing - amid fears the previous strict guidance was deterring workplaces and shopfloors from reopening.⚠️ Read our coronavirus live blog for the latest news  updatesThe tweaks offers hope to the hospitality industry by signalling that the Government is poised to relax the social distancing rules further in time for pubs and restaurants to reopen from July .The updated guidance advises companies to take “all reasonable steps” to maintain two-metre distancing in workplaces and shopfloors.But it has watered down the language on previous guidance that two-metres must be maintained at all times, saying it must now only be maintained “where possible”.The news comes as:The official government guidance suggests six measures to mitigate the risk where two-metres cannot be maintained, including limiting contact time to “as short as possible”, seating staff “back-to-back or side-to-side” and staggering arrival and departure times.The Department for Business insisted there had been no major changes to the guidance and it remained the case thatemployers cannot meet the m social distancing requirement then they should consider other mitigating actions.Yesterday the boss of the UKs largest zoo said the two-metre distancing rules is threatening the future of the industry.Dr Dominique Tropeano, of Colchester Zoo, said that in a normal summer season the Essex attraction could expect , to , visitors per day. But the number is currently limited to around , to comply with social distancing guidelines, he said.Meanwhile a YouGov survey found a half of UK businesses plan to lay off staff within three months of the furlough scheme ending.Some  per cent of business leaders said a fth or more of their staff could go.Only a third of firms said they are confident they will not have to get rid of anyone.Meanwhile another poll by Ipsos MORI showed two in five employees have concerns about their job security.Businesses are worried they cannot reopen fully from July  thanks to the m rule.Pubs and restaurants will only be able to open partially and may not take enough to stay afloat.Millions of jobs could be at riskthe m rule stays in place, experts have warned.Boris Johnson is currently overseeing a review of the m rule, with the aim to have it completed by the next review date.He has said before he wants to cut it when its safe to do so, but has issued no suggestion of when that might be.The review will take into account advice from scientists, but it will not be led by the evidence.And it will also look at the impact of the rule on the economy, too. The rule will be cut by September to allow all kids toto school, an MP suggested this morning.Geoffrey Clton Brown told the BBCs Today programme he was sure that the change would be made over the summer.In other countries the distance is .m or even one metre.But scientists here think m is safest.However, the UKs Chief Scientist Adviser Patrick Vallance said earlier this week it was not a strict rule.He said the social distancing rule was not an absolute cut-off that never changes.And he added: There are times in which this can be changed and that evidence of course can then be the basis of a policy decision on what the right distance is that should be mandated or put forward as the rule to follow.He saida relaxed version of the rule can be used in combination with other measures such as face coverings, it would be saferinfection rates continued to fall.The PM acknowledged the far-reaching effects of relaxing the social distancing rule.He said: I am all too aware the two-metre rule has big implications for schools and many other sectors.I absolutely hear those concerns, I will do everything in my power to get us back to normal as soon as possible.We must proceed carefully. To receive The Sun’s title: queen delighted royal ascot winner
story: Two-year-old Tactical stormed home to win the Windsor Castle Stakes.Racing is being held behind closed doors due to coronavirus meaning The Queen was forced to cheer her horse home on the telly.The horse owned by The Queen and ridden by James Doyle and trained by Andrew Balding was the bookies favourite.It came first minutes after The Queens other runner First Receiver had finished second in an earlier race - scuppering a chancce of two winners on day two of the festival.But it was Her Majestys first winner at the annual flat-racing gala since .Royal Ascot normally attracts , spectators a day but fans have been banned - and jockeys are even wearing face masks.John Warren, the Queens bloodstock advisor, said: I think everyone involved is absolutely thrilled - all of Her Majestys team, and obviously Andrew and his team.Throughout the conversations the Queen was saying how delighted she is to produce a two-year winner at Royal Ascot.I suspect she got a warm inner feeling from pulling this one off.The Queen watched from Windsor Castle where she remains in isolation with a team of loyal staff for  weeks during lockdown.Trainer Andrew Balding said: On racedays we tend to give the Queen a ring in the morning and give her our thoughts.We did that this morning, so she was well informed.GOT a story  RING The Sun on    or WHATSAPP on  or EMAIL exclusive@the-sunOur journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes.
