title: letters to the editor june 5 2020
story: Colin CameronUpdated:   , : amLikeGoogle +TweetEmailWant to  We value our content, so access to our full site is  only available on subscription.Your subscription entitles you to -day-a-week access to our website, plus a full digital copy of that week#s paper to read on your pc mac or mobile device.And there#s more # your subscription includes access to digital archive copies from  onwardsSir,Thank you for publishing the informative article in your May  edition about the ongoing consultation for the old Kilmartin church building, which runs to June .We would like to remind readers, particularly those who live in Slockavullin, Ford, Bridgend and Kilmichael Glassary and all the homes in between, that the consultation is for everyone who lives in the Dunadd area.So please share your views # http:dunadd.scot church  and then click #Register Your Opinion#.Gary Linstead, Dunadd Community Enterprise.Sir,Scotland#s Charity Air Ambulancemarked its seventh anniversary on May .I look back with pride and gratitude on a service that has saved and improved thousands of lives and on the organisations, communities, businesses and iniduals across Scotland who helped launch and sustain that service.None of us could have foreseen the situation we find ourselves in, as we reach this landmark seventh birthday. This is a challenging operational environment for our aircrew and an extremely dficult period for our fundraising teams as the restrictions are preventing all the events, talks and activities taking place which are so essential to help support the country#s only charity-funded helicopter air ambulance service.It costs around £ million each year to fund our Perth and Aberdeen-based helicopter air ambulances. Every penny needed to keep these two lesavers in the air seven days a week,  days a year, is donated by the people of Scotland. We receive no statutory government funding.Yet, as I reflect on how the Scottish public has risen to every request we have made of them over the past seven years, I feel confident they will not abandon #The People#s Helicopter# at this particular time of need.Please support SCAAyou can and help us celebrate the seventh anniversary of this lesaving service # your service.John Bullough, Chairman, Scotland#s Charity Air Ambulance, Perth Airport.Sir,Volunteers are always important. But in challenging times, when our communities need them most, they are invaluable.During Volunteers# Week # June  to June  # I am so proud of the Scout volunteers in Scotland. Together they are helping tens of thousands of young people gain skills for le # helping them speak up, play their part and find their place in the world.To keep everyone safe, Scouts aren#t able to meet face to face. But this hasn#t stopped our volunteers from supporting young people. So many of our brilliant leaders are still running meetings online, helping Scouts catch up with their friends and continue to earn their awards.At a time when our children#s lives are so badly disrupted, these sessions are providing a sense of normality and continuity that#s so important for their well-being. We have also been supporting families across Scotland and beyond with free resources at scouts.org.uk the-great-indoors.I#d like to say a huge thank you to all our volunteers, whether you drive the minibus, make the drinks, look after the accounts or help deliver vital skills for le. We couldn’t do it without you. Your kindness and resilience in these tough times is inspiring and is making a dference.Andrew Sharkey, chief commissioner, Scouts ScotlandAlison Macdonald replied: #Lockdown has made me realise I took the little things for granted, being able to visit family and friends whenever I like, going out for lunch, celebrating occasions and just being able to go for a drive because I can. But seeing how our wee community comes together in times of need is always inspiring. Everything from businesses volunteers adapting to supply frontline workers with much-needed supplies, to people volunteering to collect shopping and essentials for people shielding. It#s made me realise community spirit is still very much alive in Lochgilphead and all over Mid Argyll.#Belinda Braithwaite posted: #That I can find joy in small things such as the birds and connections with friends and the community. And that nature didn’t know we were in lockdown and spring sprung into le.#Duncan Black said: #What it#s made me realise is just how many people evidently long to be in Stasi-esque organisations and just how easily tyranny can be implemented under the excuse of fear or political pandering.#Fyonna Doe responded: #Not to take anything for granted, especially seeing my family and friends, going for lunches, getting my hair done # everyday things that were the norm until the lockdown.#Niamh Rodden posted: #To not take anyone or anything for granted, especially seeing family and friends. It never seemed like a big deal till now when you aren#t able to do so, especially when you have small children and grandparents are missing out on so much. But we are all keeping each other safe. Stay home unless it#s completely necessary, stay safe and hopefully the day we get to see family again won’t be far away.#Karen Pickering said: #That people do care. I never realised how much I took seeing family and friends for granted until now.#Morag Macdonald replied: #My home is my safe place and I would be in a mess without the care of my husband. How much I miss my family and how I need to hug them.#Cathie Wilson responded: #I miss my family and I can honestly put up with hubbys weird singing noises!#

title: mid argyll youth footballers show promise in strong league
story: Bruce WestUpdated:   , : amLikeGoogle +TweetEmailWant to  We value our content, so access to our full site is  only available on subscription.Your subscription entitles you to -day-a-week access to our website, plus a full digital copy of that week#s paper to read on your pc mac or mobile device.And there#s more # your subscription includes access to digital archive copies from  onwardsThis was the Lochgilphead youngsters# fourth season playing -aside football.After two seasons in the Dumbarton League, finishing second then first in the league and winning the league cup both years, the boys moved to the Glasgow League in - finishing in the top half of a very competitive Division A and making it to the final of the league cup.Another competitive season was anticipated with five new teams joining the A Division.The season started well, with Star winning all three of their league cup group games against Cambuslang Reds, Cumbernauld Colts and Glasgow Red Star -, - and -.With Cambuslang Reds and Cumbernauld Colts being new opponents this was a good start and Star qualied for the knockout stages. But the COVID- lockdown interrupted proceedings.This season’s Scottish Cup was a bit of a disappointment with Star exiting the competition in the second round after losing out to a vastly improved Dumbarton United side -. On the plus side, the first round saw Star take on Paisley League team Pollok FC and an excellent performance saw Star run out convincing winners -, one of only four defeats suffered by Pollok in all competitions.In the West Region Cup, Star progressed to the quarter-final again. A first round bye, a convincing - win against Cambuslang FA then a walkover saw the Lochgilphead youths face Paisley League A Division team Erskine.In a hard-fought encounter, Star matched Erskine for most of the game but with only  players available they couldn’t get the breakthrough they needed and eventually lost -.Star started their league campaign in September with a competitive match against new team Thorn, who transferred from Paisley A Division. Star lost -.Two strong performances in October saw Star record  a terric - win over Shettleston, last season’s league runners up, and a - win against St Patrick’s Sports Academy # an entertaining but nerve-wracking game.A mid-season stutter in November saw the Lochgilphead boys lose out to Cathcart -, then Clydebank -, both newcomers.The losing run continued into early December as Star faced last season’s champions Drumchapel Amateurs ending up down - at half-time before recovering their form with a committed second half display to pull it back to -. Unfortunately they lost out to a fourth Drumchapel goal as they chased the winner themselves.This set Star back on track as they finished the year with a hugely convincing performance, demolishing Cathcart -.January and February proved a real battle with the weather with wind, rain and freezing temperatures # often all three # only allowing four games to take place. Star secured fine victories over Busby, -, and Glasgow Red Star, -, and fought back to grind out creditable draws with Shettleston, -, and Place Park, another new team, -.Star played one league game in March before lockdown and again it was another entertaining game with a rollercoaster feel to it. Facing up to Drumchapel Amateurs, both teams played out another terric match which had everything.Coming back from a goal down and with only  men, Star played cracking football to race into a - lead but it took its toll as Drumchapel stuck to their task to draw level before adding a couple more goals to secure a win in the final five minutes.This was another fine season for Red Star s, competing well in a strong league, with only  signed players.Though the season was cut short, the boys played  games winning , drawing two and losing seven. They scored  goals and conceded  goals. There were some cracking games and the boys were looking forward to the knock-out stages of the league cup.Inconsistency probably cost Star a few more wins, but that’s what youth football development is all about and there is potential for the boys to develop.Well done from coaches and parents to the  boys who played this season – Craig Aitken, Zak Barclay, Gregor Brown, Keiran Caskie, Lewis Curran, Ruaridh Green, Woody Hoad, Alexander McLean, Conner McMurchy, Leon Murphy, Innes Paterson, Jamie Stewart and Tom West.Thanks for great support goes to sponsors Ardrishaig Community Trust, main strip, SC Crawford Building Contractors Limited, change strip and zip tops, Jewsons, tracksuits, and Mid Argyll Youth Development Services and the parents, supporters, referees and opposition teams that have made the season so enjoyable.

title: remembering donald and the brave men of st valery
story: Colin CameronUpdated:   , : amLikeGoogle +TweetEmailWant to  We value our content, so access to our full site is  only available on subscription.Your subscription entitles you to -day-a-week access to our website, plus a full digital copy of that week#s paper to read on your pc mac or mobile device.And there#s more # your subscription includes access to digital archive copies from  onwardsAt am on Friday June , pipers up and down Scotland will take to their doorsteps to play the tune #Heroes of St Valéry#.They will be commemorating the th anniversary of a Second World War battle which led to , mainly Scottish soldiers being captured. The incredible bravery of the st Highland Division, which remained on the continent after the Dunkirk evacuations and were eventually overrun at St Valéry-en-Caux, has largely been forgotten.Heavily involved in the St Valéry rearguard action was the th Battalion Argyll and Sutherland Highlanders, with young men from all over Argyll in its ranks.Surrounded by the enemy, many were killed and yet more captured, to spend the rest of the war in brutal prisoner of war camps in Germany and Poland.One young Argyll soldier was Donald McLellan from Lochgilphead. His neice Cathie McLellan contacted the Advertiser to tell her uncle#s story.#I was too young to remember him, but I know he worked as a male nurse at the Argyll and Bute Hospital before the war.#Like most of the young men in the area he and his pals had joined the territorial army and enjoyed going away to training camps and things.#When the war began Donald, not long engaged to be married, and his friends were called up with the th Argylls. After basic training in Aldershot, they were sent with the st Highland Division to northern France with the British Expeditionary Force to help defend the Maginot Line.The force was no match for Hitler#s blitzkreig and the British and French were forced to retreat to the channel ports, but a number of troops, including the st Highland Division, fought a continuous rearguard action against superior forces.Lance Corporal Donald McLellan was killed in action on June   at the age of . With him was another Lochgilphead lad, Duncan Campbell, who was taken prisoner. Duncan survived the war and lived to old age, and his son Duncan and daughter Jane still live in the Lochgilphead area.Cathie continued: #My grandmother and the family didn#t find out until after the war what had happened to Donald, but we now know he is buried in a lovely graveyard in Dunkirk.#She added: #On the th anniversary, Donald is remembered with pride and love by his neices and nephews and all the family.#Across Scotland, the charityPoppyscotland, Legion Scotland and RCET: Scotland’s Armed Forces Children’s Charity have arranged a programme of commemorative events to mark the th anniversary of St Valéry.Gordon Michie of Poppyscotland said: #St Valéry represents a hugely signicant moment in our nation’s history and it is vitally important the bravery and sacrice of the #Forgotten st# is forgotten no more.#

title: letters to the editor june 12 2020
story: Colin CameronUpdated:   , : amLikeGoogle +TweetEmailWant to  We value our content, so access to our full site is  only available on subscription.Your subscription entitles you to -day-a-week access to our website, plus a full digital copy of that week#s paper to read on your pc mac or mobile device.And there#s more # your subscription includes access to digital archive copies from  onwardsSir,I would like to take this opportunity to thank volunteers for all their help and hard work over the lockdown period.Volunteering groups have been amazing and I have personal experience of the support offered by Team Tarbert to enable others to stay safely at home.The volunteers have been compassionate and reassuring and every visit the volunteer has a cheery smile and happy wave.Thank you to all volunteers. You have made a dficult situation so much easier and it is much appreciated.Stay safe stay well.Councillor Anne Horn, Tarbert.Is it possible for the public toilet in Lochgilphead to be opened again soonthe necessary safety measures can be put in place to protect the public and staff I would suggest:I think the toilets should be available soon for the public, but more safety measures such as disinfectant hand spray would be required before they opened.Peter Laing, Lochgilphead.Dear Mr Laing,In order to focus resources on maintaining essential services, protecting frontline staff and ensuring public safety, a number of services have been suspended, including the closure of public conveniences.At this time, we do not have the resources to ensure public conveniences are regularly cleaned and maintained, furthermore we do not wish to encourage those from outlying areas to visit and risk bringing infection to the local area.We will continue to monitor the services and will re-open the public toilets when safe to do so.Sir,In condoning Dominic Cummings decision to go to Durham and Barnard Castle during lockdown, Boris Johnson has completely undermined trust in the UK Government and its efforts to control the spread of the deadly coronavirus.To trivialise his misdemeanours effectively says #it’s alright to disobey the rules#, #just follow your own instincts#. It shows contempt for those in the NHS who have risked their lives to save others. It shows contempt for those who have died without their loved ones by their side. It shows contempt for all of us who have stuck by the rules to protect our lives and the lives of others.Boris Johnson has asked us to #move on# but this issue will not go away. This is a wound that will continue to fester.Dominic Cummings continues to be a major player in government decisions and rules, those rules he so shamelessly flaunted without even an apology. He should have had the humility and integrity to resign, or been sacked by the Prime Minister.Marion Lacey, Lochgair.Sir,Organised by Scottish Land and Estates , the annual Helping it Happen Awards, which are free to enter, showcase the work done in   by businesses, farms and estates to help rural Scotland thrive.We have heard of so many wonderful examples of people working together during the COVID- pandemic, so we are especially encouraging entries to our new #Community Champion of the Year# category.If you have helped your community during the pandemic, ersied your business, are doing innovative work on your farm or perhaps you have been doing some really important work in conservation, the environment or educating youngsters about rural Scotland, you should enter # or nominate someone .The Helping it Happen Awards are sponsored by GLM and there will be a Community Champion of the Year award across five Scottish regions: North East, Highland, Central Scotland, South West and South East.To enter, visit tie SLE website or search for #Helping it Happen Awards# online. The deadline is Wednesday August .Sarah-Jane Laing, chief executive, Scottish Land and Estates.You can be big, you can be small,You can be heroes, one and all.You can be Captain Tom on his hundredth lap,Support key workers with the Thursday night clap,Provide a Care Home with protective gear,Be a voice on the phone dispelling all fear,A musician or singer putting smiles on a face,When out and about respecting other folks’ space,The company boss with a work-safe plan,A volunteer who signs up to help where she can,Raise funds like the wee boy riding his bikeOr run up and down stairs # a dad’s mountain hike,Give a shielding neighbour a friendly wave,Be an ICU nurse with a le to save.The things that you do can be big, can be small,You can be heroes, one and all.Kirstin Thompson, Lochgilphead.

title: gamers-enjoy-e-sports-success-gala-fairydean-rovers
story: A TEAM of online gamers are representing Gala Fairydean Rovers FC in a virtual football competition.Gas engineer Darren Smith, of Galashiels, helped launch an -a-side league on FIFA  in which his hometown club has been enjoying considerable success.Smith, , told the Border : ldquoConsidering itrsquos the first season, itrsquos been excellent ndash and so has the reaction wersquove got from people.The Scottish league, played on a PlayStation , contains a number of teams representing official clubs, including Berwick Rangers, Greenock Morton andEast Stirlingshire.But the Galashiels side has been performing admirably, according to Smith ndash who has his sights set on a lofty finish.ldquoWersquove only beaten twice, said Smith, whose side currently sit third. ldquoLast Sunday we got beaten and we got beaten on the first day of the season.He added: ldquoWersquore still to play the second-placed team and wersquore still to play the team at the top.ldquoI thinkwe go unbeaten and they drop a few points, itrsquos there to be done and Irsquod be happy with second place.A total of  players have signed up to Galarsquos virtual squad, with three players from the town itself.As the recruitment drive was mainly carried out through Twitter, Smith was able to procure the services of gamers from across Britain and further afield. One of the goalkeepers, for instance, lives in Egypt.Asked to describe what it is like playing a video game in co-operation with  other people, Smith indicated it has been a hugely enjoyable experience.He said: ldquoPlaying with  others is sometimes challenging when it comes to getting everyone on for a certain time.ldquoHowever, being manager of the team, I have the luxury of picking who is in the team and I have managed to get some really good guys in who are competitive but also able to enjoy playing the game, which is what its all about in the end.When the real-le football season is in full swing, Smith takes to the park for Lauder Amateur FC.But, for now, the left-back is quite happy plying his trade for Gala online - and he is already considering adding a second tier to the virtual set-up next season.ldquoThe competition gives people a place to go and relax and enjoy themselves without the stresses of les problems, he said.

title: aussie-rugby-player-caring-galashiels-lockdown
story: A KIND-HEARTED Australian rugby player has been delivering food to elderly folk in the Borders town he currently calls home.Gala RFC forward Cody Roman, , moved from Wollongong, New South Wales, in October last year.When coronavirus put paid to his plans to explore more of the Borders, he decided to channel his free time into volunteering as a driver with Food Train.He said: ldquoIrsquom fortunate that Irsquom mobile so I want to get out and help those who are less fortunate or in need."For six weeks, Cody has been dropping off food to residents who are self-isolating.He said: ldquoIt got to the end of winter and I was looking forward to seeing some nice summer days, and then this [lockdown] happened.ldquoThe club put a post on social media askingthere were any guys ready to help out with anything, like shopping or dog-walking or anything that people were unable to do now, for people who had to self-isolate.ldquoThe Food Train commented on the post, and I was like, lsquoIrsquoll do itrsquo. And Irsquove being doing it for six weeks now.ldquoItrsquos been really good ndash everyone appreciates it. Some people who live alone might not have seen anyone for a few days, so theyrsquore very happy when we come out to them and have a chat.ldquoSome of them are very excited and grateful. Some of them offer us a cup of tea and we have to let them down easy."Despite being so far from his home Down Under, Cody is coping well with the coronavirus lockdown.ldquoItrsquos not too bad, with Facebook and social media and stuff. I can just send messages and give people a call."And Irsquom pretty fortunate where I live ndash everyonersquos very friendly.

title: mountain-bikers-told-ride-within-limits-lockdown
story: MOUNTAIN bikers have been issued with guidance during lockdown.Scottish Cyclinghas outlined a series of dos and donts following the Scottish Governments go-ahead for people to exercise more than once a day.There are four rules cyclists and mountain bikers must adhere to under the new SC guidelines:Only ride from your home ndash it is not essential travel to go mountain biking or cycling and you may face enquiries from the policeyou are stopped en route or ing from a ride. All Forestry and Land Scotland car parks and trails, including the stanes sites, remain closedDo not go far ndash whilst you can go exercise for longer, we recommend riding close to where you live and not into remote areas ndash think more smaller loops rather than one longer remote rideRide well within your limits ndash only ride on trails that are that you are very confident you will be able to ride safely and within your competency. It is highly unlikely that mountain rescue are back to full operations ndash consider the fact that a full rescue may not be possible and may take longer to get to youOnly cycle with members of your own household - keep a safe distance when passing other cyclists or pedestrians.Mountain biking trails such as the stanes at Glentress, Peebles, and Innerleithen are closed until further notice to restrict travel to the trails and for safety as they are not being maintained as they were before lockdown.However, walking trails owned by Forestry and Land Scotland are open to members of the public who can access them without using transport.

title: borders-golfers-allowed-play-says-msp
story: BORDERS golfers and anglers should be allowed toto action, according to Rachael Hamilton.The Conservative MSP says she has written to the Scottish Government in a bid to get restrictions lted on outdoor activities.Mrs Hamilton said shooting and angling are among the activities which make an "immense contribution" to the rural economy.She said: "Outdoor sports, such as golfing, hiking and fishing, could take place with the necessary social distancing measures and it would not jeopardise the governmentrsquos efforts in tackling this pandemic."Prime Minister Boris Johnson announced last week that residents in England canto certain outdoor pursuits, including tennis and golf.But the Scottish Government has decided to retain the stay at home message, while now allowing people to exercise more than once a day.Mrs Hamilton, who represents Ettrick, Roxburgh and Berwickshire, says she has written to the Scottish cabinet secretary for rural economy and tourism, Fergus EwingMrs Hamilton, the shadow secretary, said: "We currently have an extraordinary situation in my constituency, around Coldstream, where people can happily fish in the English half of the River Tweed, whilst anglers in Scotland can only watch on from the Scottish side, where fishing is still not permitted at this time."By their nature, outdoor-based sports see participants spread out, whether over a hillside, across an open space or along a river."In the Borders and across rural Scotland, the angling and shooting industry needs to have clarity so it can plan for the new season."I urge the Scottish Government to rethink its restrictions, given the nature of these sports, and the immense contribution they make to our rural economy."

title: selkirk-rugby-players-bid-clean-town
story: HAVING just completed a sponsored charity project that raised almost pound, in under a fortnight for the townrsquos foodbank, Selkirk Rugby Clubrsquos players arenrsquot letting the grass grow under their feet.This week members of the clubrsquos playing squad have embarked on yet another lsquochallengersquo to support the local community ndash litter collection.The idea came from former st XV skipper Ross Nixon, and comes in the wake of a similar venture undertaken by Glasgow Warriorsrsquo professional players.ldquoWhen yoursquore walking in and around Selkirk, you canrsquot help noticing pieces of litter that have been left lying around, often when proper bins arenrsquot that far away, said Nixon.ldquoI thought it would be a good idea for Selkirk players to take a bin bag with them when they head out to take their daily exercise, picking up any litter they see next to paths or along roadside verges.ldquoWersquore lucky in Selkirk to have such unspoilt countryside to exercise in, so itrsquos a shame to see it spoiled by discarded empty bottles, food wrappers and general rubbish.ldquoI kicked off the campaign by nominating three members of our players ndash Aaron McColm, Ewan MacDougall and Liam Cassidy ndash to collect litter on their walks.ldquoEach of this trio will then challenge a further three players to collect litter, and in turn these three will nominate other team-mates, and so on.The project has the backing of Selkirk head coach Scott Wight.He said: ldquoItrsquos another way the club can put something back into the local community, though this time therersquos no sponsorship involved.ldquoItrsquos looking asitrsquos going to be a wee while before any rugby is going to be played, so this latest effort not only helps keep the players in touch with each other, itrsquos also providing a useful service for the Selkirk community.Meanwhile, Selkirk Rugby Club is to stage its annual Players Presentation Night on Fridayndash although this yearrsquos event will be a lsquovirtualrsquo get-together.The plan is for the clubrsquos coaches, players and rugby officials to be digitally linked via Zoom, with Selkirk head coach Scott Wight taking charge of proceedings.ldquoThe idea is to try and stick as closely as possible to the format normally used at the clubrsquos annual presentation nights, said Wight.ldquoA total of nine trophies are up for grabs, and the name of each award winner will be announced separately on the video link, followed by film footage, or photos, of that player in a match situation.ldquoShort addresses will be given by, among others, the clubrsquos chairman and its director of rugby, as well as recaps of the st and lsquoArsquo XVsrsquo seasons by the sidesrsquo respective team managers."It should be a fun evening!

title: rugby-players-hailed-helping-prepare-golf-course
story: GALA rugby players have been thanked for helping to prepare a local golf course for reopening.Torwoodlee Golf Club welcomed members back on Fridayafter First Minister Nicola Sturgeon eased lockdown restrictions.Club chairman Robin Brydon said greenkeepers had been helped by Gala RFC players.He thanked the volunteers for their "great efforts" in rolling turf and raking bunkers.Gala president Ian Dalgleish said: ldquoWersquod be delighted to help other local sports clubs and organisations in these times ndash get in touch."You can contact the rugby club through its Facebook page or by emailing info@galarfc

title: interview-borders-book-festival-prepares-go-online
story: CELEBRITY guests have been a staple of the Borders Book Festival since its launch in .Clearly, festival founder Alistair Moffat has no shortage of impressive contacts to draw upon.Yet some readers might be surprised to learn the identities of the pair he would most like to see in Melrose.ldquoAnt and Dec, blurts Moffat, , without a momentrsquos hesitation.Describing the Geordie duo as ldquogreat guys, he says: ldquoIrsquove been trying to persuade them and they know Irsquoll never give up ndash and theyrsquoll crumble one day.This year, though, there will not be a famous face in sight within the walled gardens of Harmony House.With coronavirus restrictions putting paid to any chance of a physical gathering, the showcase ndash which was originally planned for this weekend ndash is set to take a virtual form.Beginning on July , authors will star in events available for streaming from the festival website.Moffat is still in the middle of booking guests, but he has already snapped up some well-known figures, as ever.ldquoIn a way, itrsquos easier for people, he says, ldquobecause all they have to do is sit in front of their laptop camera ndash they donrsquot have to come to Melrose.Itrsquos now looking more likely than not that Moffat and his fellow directors will triumph over the obstacles posed by COVID-.But back in March, when the virus began to take hold in Britain, a sense of despondency hung over the group.ldquoWe were absolutely heartbroken, because virtually all of our work had been done by then, says Moffat.As it became clearer that a physical event would not be possible, Moffat and his colleagues realigned their ambitions and channelled their energies into simply making sure that the festival would survive.To Moffatrsquos relief, the idea of an online version found favour with sponsors and the Friends of the Festival.ldquoOnly three people wanted their money back and whatrsquos amazing is we had a tsunami of supportive emails from the public, says Moffat, calling the response ldquovery moving.Everyone will be able to watch the streamed events without paying a penny, says Moffat, with viewers merely invited to make a donationthey can afford it.ldquoSome festivals have charged for these things, but we donrsquot think thatrsquos right, says Kelso-born Moffat, himself an author of more than  books.ldquoWersquoll invite people to donatethey wish, but these are hard times ndash people need to put food on the table.Notwithstanding his delight at being able to run the festival this year, despite the dficult conditions, Moffat is already looking forward to theof a physical format.ldquoTherersquos nothing like being in the same place as Melvyn Bragg or Joanna Lumley or Gordon Brown and being able to ask them questions, says Moffat.,params: .pushThe appeal of the Borders Book Festival, according to its founder, lies in the eventrsquos ldquosociability.ldquoThe famous people are not all herded off into a sealed container ndash theyrsquore there to talk to you, says Moffat.ldquoPeople who are extremely well-known, that all peels away and wersquoll see them standing chatting.Which brings us neatly to comedy twosome Ant and Dec, the showbiz stars whose presence Moffat so dearly craves.ldquoWhat people would see from Ant and Dec is just something completely dferent, he says, admiringly, having known the TV personalities for many years.The pair have a book coming out this year, according to Moffat ndash so perhaps his dream might yet come true.Full details of the virtual events, set to run for  weeks, will be published at: www.bordersbookfestival.org

title: ant-dec-apologise-using-blackface-saturday-night-takeaway
story: ANT and Dec have apologised for using blackface on old episodes of theirITV Saturday Night Takeaway show.The pair used darker makeupand wore prosthetics for the undercover sketch, in which they pranked famous faces while in disguise.The presenting pair said they would not make those sketches today and had requested ITV, which broadcasts the show, remove them from their streaming catch-up service.What have Ant and Dec said A statement on their Instagram and Twitter accounts said: ldquoDuring past episodes of Saturday Night Takeaway we impersonated people of colour in the Undercover segment of the show.ldquoWe realise that this was wrong and want to say that we are sincerely sorry to everyone that we offended.ldquoWe purposely stopped doing this several years ago and certainly would not make these sketches today.ldquoWe had already taken steps to ensure footage was taken down and have again recently confirmed with ITV that these segments, and any other historical content that could cause offence, does not appear on either the ITV Hub or the Saturday Night Takeaway YouTube Channel.When did the pair wear blackface The pair wore blackface in  as they dressed up as two fictional Jamaican women, Patty and Bernice, to prank Emmerdale cast members.And in  they dressed up as two Japanese girls, Suki and Keiko, using make-up and exaggerated accents.Comedy shows removed and further apologies issuedIt comes after Little Britain was removed from iPlayer after coming under fire because of the use of blackface in some sketches.Walliams sported black make-up and a large afro wig to play the overweight black woman Desiree DeVere.Lucas also used blackface to play Pastor Jesse King, who said he was ldquofrom the ghetto and spoke in tongues to cure the sick." alt"Border : Apology: Little Britains Matt Lucas and David Walliams " class"editor-image"Apology: Little Britains Matt Lucas and David Walliams Last week, comedian Leigh Francis issued a tearful apology for portraying black celebrities on sketch show Borsquo Selecta.Black Lives Matter protests have taken place around the world following the death of unarmed black man George Floyd in the US after a police officer knelt on his neck, prompting greater scrutiny over the use of blackface in the media.

title: borders-festival-blackening-faces-cannot-go
story: FESTIVAL organisers in Peebles say they will not tolerate participants ldquoblackening their faces.The Beltanecommittee published a statement on June  after social media users expressed disappointment that some revellers had worn ldquoethnic makeup over the years.Beltane organisers said in their statement: ldquoWe can confirm that the committee has not and will never condone or tolerate anyone taking part in our fancy dress competition and parade who has blackened their face.In the statement, the committee says it has recently been asked to review ldquocultural appropriation and ldquoblackening of faces, adding that it is seeking help from a lawyer to make sure its guidance on equality matters is appropriate.However, the statement says there are some changes which ldquocannot happen overnight.In an attempt to offer clarication, the committeersquos secretary George Blair told this newspaper: "These are committee decisions. Our committee cant operate over Zoom as some are not tech-savvy.He added: "If we were to withdraw  costumes, wed have to replace them with something dferent."Some of the issues raised are valid and were going to change these things."The committee says it did not receive a complaint before its recent annual general meeting, going on to express disappointment that any concerns were not put forward directly.Looking to the future, Mr Blair, , encourages people to contact the committee with any complaints, including those around racism and racist behaviour.He said: "We want everyone to be on the same side."Peebles is a predominantly white town, but anyone of any creed or colour can join us."Wed love to see more people."Changes to costuming at the festival were made in  when complaints were lodged over the Nursery Rhymes Come to Le dress-up theme where golliwog costumes were worn ndash and subsequently banned.Recently, an online petition has been circulated asking the committee to make further changes to its costume guidelines. The committee says it will do this before next yearrsquos event.

title: find-winner-walter-scott-prize-2020
story: THE winner of the Walter Scott Prize for Historical Fiction will be announced tomorrow .A ceremony had originally been scheduled to take place at the Borders Book Festival.But the festival was cancelled due to coronavirus restrictions, so the winner will be declared on BBC Radio  instead.To hear the announcement, you can tune in to the channels Front Row programme at .pm.The organisers of the competition hope a formal ceremony can be held at Abbotsford later in the year.The shortlist was revealed in March.Previous winners include Hilary Mantel, Andrea Levy, Sebastian Barry, Tan Twan Eng, Robert Harris, John Spurling, Simon Mawer, Benjamin Myers and Robin Robertson.This is the shortlist for the prizeThe Narrow Land by Christine Dwyer HickeyThe Parisian by Isabella HammadTo Calais, In Ordinary Time by James MeekShadowplay by Joseph OrsquoConnorThe Redeemed by Tim PearsA Sin of Omission by Marguerite Poland

title: coronavirus-almost-13-000-workers-borders-furloughed
story: ALMOST , workers in the Borders have been furloughed since the start of the coronavirus pandemic.The Coronavirus Job Retention Scheme was launched back in April.And of the , workers in the region, a total of , are having  per cent of their wages paid by the government.John Lamont, MP for Berwickshire, Roxburgh and Selkirk, said: "This historic intervention by the Chancellor, Rishi Sunak, has ensured that thousands of people still have a job toto, despite the problems caused by coronavirus. It is reassuring that so many businesses and employees have been able to make use of this scheme."The UK Government is doing whatever it takes to get the Scottish Borders, Scotland and the whole country through this crisis. I am grateful to the hard work of civil servants and ministers for putting these packages in place so quickly."Nevertheless, I am very aware of the economic hit that will come from the pandemic."Unfortunately, we have already seen some indication from Borders businesses that there will be challenging times ahead."The scheme was also praised by secretary of state for Scotland, Alister Jack.He added: ldquoSo far, nearly , jobs across Scotland have been saved by direct UK Government coronavirus support. Through the job retention scheme , Scottish jobs have been furloughed, and the UK Government has spent pound million on supporting , self-employed people in ScotlandldquoIn the South of Scotland alone that amounts to more than , jobs saved. Rural communities such as ours face particular challenges and Irsquom very pleased that the UK Government has been able to step in."

title: no-redundancies-furlough-insists-stobo-castle
story: THE chairman of Stobo Castle insists staff will not be made redundant while the furlough scheme is in place.Stephen Winyard gave  workers his assurances this week.It comes after the Crieff Hydro and Macdonald hotel groups announced jobs are at risk in Peebles and Cardrona respectively.Mr Winyard said: ldquoWe were all hugely saddened to hear the devastating news of , redundancies at Macdonald Hotels and a further  within the Crieff Hydro Group that will respectively lead to signicant job losses at the nearby Cardrona Macdonald Hotel and Peebles Hydro."To address any understandable concerns, we have given a categorical assurance to our  strong workforce that no redundancies will take place before the end of the furlough scheme on October ."In a statement, Mr Winyard also called on the Scottish Government to relax social distancing rules, to help businesses in the hospitality industry.He added: "We have secured funding through the governmentrsquos Coronavirus Business Interruption Loan Scheme to finance the incremental contribution that all employers are required to make from August  to the cost of the Job Retention Scheme."However the hospitality industry will undoubtedly require further state support to ensure its survival through the long winter months."In their update on June , I am calling for the Scottish Government to halve social distancing from July ."This will allow the hospitality industry to prepare for re-opening on July  at a capacity that is financially viable."This, of course, is subject to the R rate continuing to fall and there is no indication of a second wave of the virus."The Job Retention Scheme was created to enable businesses to preserve their loyal and dedicated workforces for when they re-open and that is exactly what we plan to do."The welfare of the Stobo team is our top priority and we do hope that other businesses in the hospitality sector will follow suit, thereby sustaining the tourism industry that is so vital to the economy of the Scottish Borders."

title: can-take-recycling-centres-borders
story: MORE types of waste can now be taken to Borders tips.As previously reported, recycling centres are now open to the public.And this week, Scottish Borders Council has said that some large items will now be accepted.They include mattresses, plastic garden furniture, kitchen units, carpet, wood and wooden furniture.However, residents are still unable to take household electrical appliances, such as fridges, TVs and microwaves and metal objects.Cardboard is also not being accepted and should be flat packed and put alongside kerbside recycling bins for collection.A maximum of five bin bags of waste are allowed per visit, including a limit of two large general waste or wood items.Scottish Borders Councilrsquos chief executive Tracey Logan said: ldquoThank you to members of the public who have attended our recycling centres and complied with the temporary restrictions so far, which has allowed us to now accept more waste types.ldquoThe restrictions will continue to be reviewed and adjusted as we move forward, with any changes communicated in advance.ldquoWe would continue to ask anyone using a community recycling centre to follow the restrictions and guidance we have in place, and treat our staff with respect.The full list of restrictions can be viewed by clicking here.

title: football-memorabilia-items-worth-fortune
story: FOOTBALL fans have been urged to check their lofts as they could be sitting on a small fortune.From classic replica shirts to sticker albums, many could be sitting ona miniaturegoldmine without even knowing it.If you manage to get your hands on the right item at the right time, you could secure a tidy profit.Do you know what to look for and how much an item you already own in storage could be worth Research has identied exactly which football-related keepsakes have the most value in .Herersquos a snapshot of some ofthe most popular football memorabilia.A David Beckham Manchester United home shirt from their treble-winning  season is worth pound..The - season Liverpool home shirt fetches pound online, and the Arsenal - away shirt can be worth pound.The prices of other rare items, including medals, sticker albums and programmes, have also shot up and they can sell for hundreds.The complete Panini France rsquo World Cup sticker album is now worth pound.If you are lucky enough to own any of these items, then congratulations - you could sell for a nice profit. Alternatively, keeping it may well provide sentimental value. Either way, itrsquos a win-win.If you have something you think is of value, or thinking of buying a collectable, these are the main things to look out for.Age:anything more than  years old is most collectable. Whatrsquos in your grandadrsquos shed Rarity:there are many available, this will bring the value down. Not everyonersquos been to an FA Cup Final ... anything final-related holds a lot of value. Cup final programmes are always of a high value.Popularity:programmes with an iconic footballer on the cover or detailing a famous match are the most prized and valuable. A footballerrsquos or managerrsquos last game for a club increases the match day programmersquos value - so itrsquos worth checking.Condition:it goes without saying that creases, missing staples and water damage all harm the price of the memorabilia.With the Premier League season back on, now could be a great time to dust off any memorabilia yoursquove had for the past few decades.

title: walter-scott-prize-2020-success-christine-dwyer-hickey
story: IRISH author Christine Dwyer Hickey has won pound, after claiming the Walter Scott Prize for Historical Fiction .Judges considered her novel The Narrow Landto be a ldquomasterpiece for its portrayal of Edward and Jo Hopperrsquos marriage.In a video acceptance speech, Ms Hickey said: ldquoI really, really appreciate this recognition.The winner was originally going to be announced at the Borders Book Festival in Melrose, but coronavirus restrictions forced a change of plan.Ms Hickeyrsquos book about the marriage of two American artists led to her triumphing over fellow authors Joseph OrsquoConnor, Isabella Hammad, James Meek, Tim Pears and Marguerite Poland.Ms Hickey said: ldquoWriting a novel takes a big chunk of onersquos le - The Narrow Landwas six years in the making - which is why I really, really appreciate this recognition.ldquoI would like to send my thoughts to a grave in a hillside cemetery in Nyack, overlooking the Hudson river, a few miles from New York City, where the artists Edward and Jo Hopper lie, and where I hope they have at last found peace.ldquoI also hope they will forgive me the intrusion.The judging  consisted of Elizabeth Buccleuch, James Holloway, Elizabeth Laird, Jim Naughtie, Kirsty Wark and chairwoman Katie Grant.Their joint statement reads: ldquoItrsquos a risky business, portraying the marriage of two artists, particularly when both the marriage and the art have already been picked over by biographers and art historians.ldquoChristine Dwyer Hickey has embraced the risk and created a masterpiece.ldquoIn The Narrow Land, she reaches into the guts of the marriage of Jo and Edward Hopper and into the heart of the creative impulse itself. And more, much more.ldquoQuietly, inexorably, and with pinpoint perception, our winner has brought to dramatic le not just the Hoppersrsquo intimate eruptions but the tensions and complexities in those around them, from two young boys scarred by war to the transient summer crowd at Cape Cod, and though this forensic lens we glimpse the upheavals that were to shake all Americans in the post-war world.ldquoWith the pull of a shting sea, The Narrow Landdrew the judges back again and again, each reading richer than the one before.The Walter Scott Prize, founded in , rewards the best fiction set  years ago or more. It is open to authors from the UK, Ireland and the Commonwealth.This years prize-winner was announced on BBC Radio  at .pm on June .

title: racism-borders-sisters-tell-story
story: GROWING up as mixed-race girls in the Borders was often a struggle, according to sisters Sara and Hannah Alkashmim.Faeces smeared on their door handles. Gravy-filled condoms thrown at their doorstep. Windows smashed and tyres slashed.These are examples of the racist attacks that the Alkashmim family say they have endured over the last three decades, with some episodes leading to court cases.As the daughters of a white mother and an Arabian father from Yemen, Sara and Hannah stood out when they attended Peebles Priorsford Primary School and, later, the towns high school.Now living and working in Edinburgh as nursery teachers, the pair feel confident to share the horrors they faced during their childhood ndash in the hope of changing attitudes in the region.The abuse started early for -year-old Sara and Hannah, , who can remember being called racial slurs in primary school.They continued to be targeted throughout their teenage years, they say.Former Beltane Queen Sara recalls being assaulted in Galashiels when walking to the bus station after college.She said: "Three girls, who I had already reported to the police, attacked me behind the bus station."They kicked and hit me, called me names which included racial slurs, and stole my phone."And when Hannah was  or , she says, she was whipped on the back of the leg with a metal dog lead, resulting in heavy bruising needing medical attention.Hannah said: "It was the build-up of years of racial comments, of being sent memes of women in burqas, of casual racist chanting directed towards me, and I just had enough. I had to go to the police."Although racism was not their only reason for moving away, Sara says they wanted a ldquofresh start."I never planned on staying, but I did feel like I couldnt stay there anymore because of the racism, said Sara.The sisters believe the best way to tackle some of the racist attitudes in Peebles, whether intentional or unintentional, is through education.Sara said: "Racism is throughout Scotland but I think it can be worse in rural areas."We didnt learn anything in school about racism, black history or dferent cultures."If people were able to call us names as early as primary two or three, then these issues need to be addressed in the curriculum as early as that, too."Hannah added: "We dont want to just share our stories and thats it.ldquoThere needs to be positive change and the best way to do that is through education.Sara and Hannah attended the Black Lives Matter protest in Edinburgh last Sunday , where they obeyed social distancing rules while wearing masks and gloves.The global movement has inspired the sisters to voice their own struggles on social media.,params: .pushNow self-isolating for two weeks following the protest, Hannah said: "Its the first time that people are really listening.ldquoA lot of people dont want to talk about racism, its uncomfortable, but were finally starting to have these conversations."Its given me the confidence that were not going to get shut down. People do care, and they want to help."However, we have had a bit of backlash from some people from Peebles who feel like were putting the town down."But we cant deny what happened to us. We cant be dishonest and say it was only a few people, because it wasnt."Were not saying that everyone in Peebles is racist and its not always intentional."Sara added: "I still think theres lots of people who disagree and think there isnt actually any racism in Peebles."Its important to make it clear racism still happens across Scotland, including in Peebles currently."We love the town. Its a beautul place but there is definitely room for improvement when it comes to tackling racism."

title: scotlands-lockdown-easing-scottish-spca-advice-dog-owners-know
story: DOG owners are being urged to start preparing for the easing of lockdown in Scotland ndash with our furry friends facing separation anxiety after months of extra human contact.Before tighter measures were introduced, most dogs were likely suited to the routine of their owners ndash which included being left indoors while they went out for work.But since March, thousands more people in Scotland have been working from home.The immediate impact would, of course, prove to be popular with your four-legged friend ndash however animal experts are warning of the consequences once lockdown ends.Speaking to Radio Clyde News, Alan Grant from the Scottish SPCA said there will likely be ldquoteething problems for dogs as measures ease further and office working s.He told the radio station: ldquoDogs are much like us, any change to the routine or their day-to-day le is going to have an impact on them.ldquoWersquove all had to change and work from home and adapt our working protocols, which has been dficult for us at the beginning but wersquore now more used to it. Itrsquos the same for the dogs.ldquoDogs may have been a bit unsettled at the beginning with the owners being there but theyrsquove now adapted to that situation ndash and itrsquos now about adapting to going back to the old situation of the owner not being there, and thatrsquos where there will be a bit of teething problems for a lot of people at the beginning.So what can I do The Scottish SPCA have urged owners to start with "micro" changes now- leaving their dogsfor a short period of time with something to keep them occupied.They also suggest investing in a camera to have a greater understanding of your dogs behaviour when you are not there.Mr Grant continued: "We want to start right now with very small changes, we call it stress inoculation. If we never leave our dogs, theyrsquore never going to get used to it."So we would leave them for micro amounts of time ndash but wersquod do a lot of stuff before we went to leaving them."Wersquod look at their day-to-day le and how can we make that le more enriching."Are they food motivated  If so, can we give them something that will take them five or ten minutes to eat, while we leave for five or ten minutes ndash then see how they are."Something  that is a great idea is to get a camera and see how your dog is actually behaving when you go out."That way yoursquoll know whether they go sleep for half an hour and then get up and start panting or is it immediately when we leave."They seem to cope well Mr Grant told the radio stationit is "imporant" to know how your dog reacts to being left on its own.He continued: "If they are confident being left on their own for a short while, then we probably donrsquot need to deal with separation anxiety because they can cope being left.,params: .push"If that is the case, we just need to build up on that time that they are on their own."Something like getting a camera can be very much to your advantage so we know what we are dealing with ndash perhaps revealing that they can cope fine but just get bored, so we can enrich their le and give them other things to do so that they are not as bored when you go out."What they struggle This likely means your dog suffers from seperation anxiety.Symptoms of this includeyour dog starts pacing and panting the moment you leave the door.In that case, Mr Grant says, you "would maybe need to look at some form of tailored programme for your particular dogthat is the case ndash but without knowing that itrsquos very hard to make that call."You can find our more information from the Scottish SPCA here.

title: scotlands-schools-lockdown-five-key-updates-nicola-sturgeons-announcement
story: THE First Minister has today tried to address the concerns from ldquoanxious parents and students about the impact of coronavirus on schooling.Speaking about plans for Scottish youngsters toto school from August , Nicola Sturgeon said there should be ldquono doubt about the priority the government is giving education ndash to ldquomake sure young people do not lose out on education or have their le chances damaged.It comes as no new coronavirus deaths were reported in Scotland in the last  hours ndash the third time the figure has remained the same since lockdown began.A total of  patients have died in Scotland after testing positive for coronavirus, no change on Sundayrsquos figure.The death total previously remained the same on June  and June  -but the First Minister stressed that deaths are lower at weekends.What did the First Minister say about education . lsquoMaximisersquo in-school learningMs Sturgeon says ministers expectcouncils to put in place arrangements that ldquoabsolutely maximise the amount of time youngsters spend in school.The majority of pupils from Scotland have not been in the classroom since March.ldquoThe Scottish Government will be scrutinising council plans very closely, Ms Sturgeon said.ldquoWhere we conclude all possible steps have not been taken to maximise face to face teaching and learning, we will ask councils to reconsider and revise their plans.ldquoWhere there are genuine issues of resources the Scottish Government will work with councils to address those..lsquoBlendedrsquo learning for less than a yearThe First Minister said she wants blended learning - where kids have a mix of in-school and at-home education - to be no longer needed by the end of the next academic year.Ms Sturgeon said: ldquoOur aim will be toto normal schooling as quickly as we possibly can, recognising that along the way we must build the confidence of parents, young people and teachers that schools are safe.ldquoIt is absolutely not the case that we are planning for blended learning, with children learning at home for part of the school week, to last a year or anything like it.ldquoOn the contrary, we do not want blended learning to last a single second longer than is absolutely necessary, so we will be working with councils toschools to normal as quickly as we can.ldquoWe want young people to be back having face-to-face teaching for % of the school week as soon as it is feasible.. Next yearrsquos exams The First Minister made clear it was the Governmentrsquos ldquoclear intention that exams will go ahead in in .This comes after comments from Education Secretary John Swinney, who revealed local authorities are being given guidance to gather evidence of grades in case exams cannot go ahead.,params: .push. Holidays cancelled or weekend schooling After being questioned by journalists on the issue, the First Minister said the Scottish Government would not rule out cancelling further school holidays, including the October break, to allow pupils to maximise time in class.Likewise, Ms Sturgeon added they also will not rule out opening schools on a Saturdaythere is evidence it will help.ICYMI - todayrsquos @scotgovdaily update focused on school education and the importance of getting it back to normal as quickly as we safely can. https:t.co cnzkwVbmdash Nicola SturgeonJune , . Regular reviewsThe Scottish Governmentrsquos regular three-weekly reviews of coronvirus restrictions will now include specic consideration of the evidence and data relating to transmission of the virus within schools and young people, she added.She pledged: ldquoWhere that suggests that safety and restrictions can belted or eased without putting pupils and teachers at undue risk we will do so.The Scottish Governmentrsquos International Council of Education Advisers will also consider the experience in out countries, Ms Sturgeon added.Nicola Sturgeon went on to state the Scottish Government would be working with councils to ensure ldquoenhanced support is available ldquofor any time that young people do spend learning at home.

title: douglas-crawfords-message-melrose-festival-fans
story: THIS week should have seen Melrose mark its annual festival.However, the event is among the many postponed due to coronavirus restrictions.Melrosian-elect Douglas Crawford and festival chairman Rob Moffat have issued a video message on Facebook.Douglas said: "Obviously its very sad that were unable to celebrate the festival this week, but I hope youre managing to stay safe and well during whats been a dficult and challenging time for everyone."I know Harry [Fletcher], Ben [Magowan] and myself were really looking forward not only to the Melrose week, but also all the other towns summer and celebrate the festival."But until then, stay safe and hopefully see you all soon."Douglas, , was announced as the Melrosian-elect in January at the annual Ex-Melrosian Burns Supper.He was a lot of fun and enjoyment."I feel very sorry for Douglas Crawford, who would have been and will be an excellent Melrosian in the future and its very dficult for the pupils of Primary , the Queen and title: virtual-beltane-festival-begins-peebles
story: A VIRTUAL Beltane Festival is under way in Peebles.The physical event was cancelled due to coronavirus restrictions.But residents are nevertheless being urged to take part in a range of activities this week.In a video message posted on Facebook, festival chairman Paul Spence said: "We still wanted to ensure we marked the occasion in the best way that we can."Mr Spence called on residents to "turn the town red and white".He said: "Lets get the bunting up, lets celebrate our great festival and,you want, include some previous house decorations."He also invited people to update their social media profiles with red-and-white images and pictures of previous festivals."Lets get as many great memories on social media as possible," he said.More information on events being held this week can be found on the Beltane Facebook page, said Mr Spence.Activities include a quiz on June  and a couple of virtual discos.

title: face-masks-wear-one-properly-stop-glasses-steaming
story: A NEW law means that face coverings are now compulsory acrossEngland when using public transport.Some form of facial protection must be worn for commuters to be able to travel on public trains and buses as of today , with the law to be enforced by transport operators and British Transport police ldquo necessary.Travellers can be fined and refused travelthey do not comply with the law.Very young children, disabled people and those who have breathing dficulties are exempt from the rules, but all other public transport users must comply fromJune .At the time of publication - similar rules regarding face masks and public transport have not been implemented across Scotland, Walesand Northern Ireland.But which types of face coverings are acceptable, and how do you wear them properly How do I wear a face mask properly The UK Government has advised that scarves, or homemade cotton coverings, that cover the nose and mouth are fine to wear- so, too, arebought masks that are not the same as those used by the health service.Surgical masks should be kept for use by health professionals.Officials have said that people can make a face covering at home, but added it is key to ensure it covers your nose and mouth.Government guidancestates that a cloth face covering should cover your mouth and nose while allowing you to breathe comfortably. This can be as simple as a scarf or bandana that ties behind the head.Before putting it on, you should wash your hands or use hand sanitiser and do the same after removing it.Avoid touching your eyes, nose, or mouth at all times and store any used face coverings in a plastic bag until you have an opportunity to wash them.Do not touch the front of the face covering, or the part of the face covering that has been in contact with your mouth and nose.Once removed, make sure you clean any surfaces the face covering has touched and wash the covering regularly. The covering can be washed with other laundry, using your normal detergent.When wearing a face covering, take care to tuck away any loose ends.How do I stop my glasses from steaming up If you wear glasses, wearing a face mask at the same time can cause the lenses to steam up, making it dficult to see properly.But the common problem has an easy solution, thanks to advice from doctors in the medical journal Annals of the Royal College of Surgeons of England.To prevent the issue, doctors advise washing your glasses with soapy water before putting the mask on, and rinsing them under warm water.Then, gently dry off the lenses with a clean towel or cloth before putting them back on.Washing the lenses with soapy water leaves behind a ldquothin surfactant film that reduces misting on the lenses, meaning they now shouldnrsquot steam up when a face mask is worn.Should face coverings be worn where The current government advice states that face coverings should be worn in enclosed spaces, which includes some shops and public transport.At the moment, people are not being told to wear them outdoors, while exercising, or in schools or offices.Several airlines, including easyJet and Ryanair, have introduced a requirement for passengers to wear face masks on board.However, the government believes that face masks should be reserved for people who need them to protect against risks in their workplace, such as health and care workers.

title: borders-priest-moving-rome-new-job
story: A BORDERS priest has accepted a high-ranking job in Rome.Nick Welsh, , has been based in Galashiels for the past two years.But he will soon be flying out to Italy after being picked for the role of vice-rector at the Scots College, where aspiring Scottish priests receive their training.Father Nick, originally from Stirling, told the Border he had ldquomixed emotions when he heard the news.He said: ldquoIrsquom quite excited, but Irsquoll have a bit of a heavy heart when I leave ndash I was just getting used to the Borders.Since , Father Nick has been administrator of the Parish of Our Lady  St Andrew, which has churches in Galashiels, Melrose and Selkirk.He said: ldquoI was really warmly welcomed here. Irsquom a bit of a city boy, but I was very much welcomed into a place I was very unfamiliar with.Asked what his favourite parts of the job have been, he highlighted working with local children, saying: ldquoIt was a really great thing to be involved with the schools here.His routine has seen him leading services in Galashiels , Melroseand Selkirk .But he has also visited the Borders General Hospital and people who are unable to leave home due to illness.Last week, however, he received a surprise phone call saying he had been selected for the Scots College job.ldquoI was a student there from -, so itrsquos a very familiar place but it was quite a surprise to me to be asked to go back, Father Nick said.ldquoIrsquove only been here for two years and I thought I would be here for a bit longer.ldquoOften you would be in a place for  years before you move on.Father Nick was happy to accept the new post, though, having enjoyed living in the Italian capital previously.ldquoI loved living in Rome so Irsquom quite excited about moving back, he said.ldquoI love being a priest and helping others to become a priest will be something Irsquoll be quite energised by.Father Nick, who intends to fly out in August, will be second-in-command and will take care of the administration of the college.He says he will also teach priests ldquohow to preach and give guidance on ldquopractical aspects of the job.The Scots College currently boasts three Borderers in its ranks, according to Father Nick ndash including former disc jockey Bobby Taylor from Galashiels.Josh Moir is also from Galashiels, while Martin Eckersley is from Jedburgh.

title: easyjet-restarts-flights-full-list-destinations-can-fly
story: Easyjet has restarted a small number of its flightsto a limited amountof destinations withstricter cleaning and safety measures for staff and passengers.Heres a round-up ofeverything you need to know.When did Easyjet restart flights Easyjet relaunched its flights from  airports across Europe for the first time on Monday, June , since they were halted at the end of March due to the coronavirus pandemic.The first flight from the UK took off on Monday morning from London Gatwick at am for Glasgow, which was the same flight path the airline first took when it launched in November .What destinations is Easyjet flying to Easyjet will be offering a reduced roster of destinations available for passengers - the plan is to be able to fly  per cent of its normal , routes in July, and  per cent in August.While there will be fewer flights on offer, travellers will have their pick of flights to domestic, city and beach destinations.These are all the destinations available from the Easyjet summer  flying programme:AlbaniaAustriaBelgiumBulgariaCroatiaCyprusCzech RepublicDenmarkEgyptEstoniaFranceGermanyGibraltarGreeceHungaryIcelandIsraelItalyKosovoMontenegroMoroccoNetherlandsPolandPortugalSerbiaSloveniaSpainSwedenSwitzerlandTurkeyCities around the UKThe airline confirmed that flights will resume from airports across the UK, including:London GatwickBristolBirminghamLiverpoolNewcastleEdinburghGlasgowInvernessBelfastWhat are the increased safety measures for staff and passengers Easyjet has introduced extra safety measures in order to keep staff and passengers safe during their flights.Additional cleaning and disinfection procedures for aircraft cabins will be in place, with every aircraft subject to a daily disinfection process.All passengers and crew will be required to wear masks at all times. The airline has also teamed up with a superhero illustrator to create comic book-inspired face masks for children.Artist Will Sliney is best known for his work on Marvel comics, like Spiderman and Star Wars.Aircrafts will be fully equipped with sanitary equipment - including masks, gloves and hand sanitiser -which will be available to customers and crew throughout the flight, where required.The aircraft are also fitted with ldquostate of the art filtration technology which ldquofilters . per cent of airborne contaminants in the cabin, including virus and bacteria, according to a statement from Easyjet.

title: free-school-meals-extended-scotland-summer---know
story: THE First Minister has today announced that free school meals will be extended in Scotland throughout the summer.It comes as the UK Government has become embroiled in a row over its decision not to extend their scheme in England - with Manchester United footballer Marcus Rashford pleading for a U-turn.Speaking at her daily briefing in Edinburgh today, in which she revealed a further five available to around , children across Scotland, either within local authority premises which are still open or through direct cash payments, supermarket vouchers or the direct supply of meals."I can also important to the health and wellbeing of young children.ldquoWe will provide pound. million in funding to local authorities to enable the continuation of free school meals during the period from title: runner-ticking-off-borders-towns---seen-yet
story: A GALASHIELS man is running through a dozen towns for a fundraiser in memory of his late sister.Craig Lowrie, , challenged himself to complete km in each town during the common riding season.Mr Lowrie is dedicating his efforts to his late sister Donna Cameron, who died in a car crash on June , .The keen amateur footballer said: "The money that I raise in my sisters memory will be split between common riding committees across the Borders, with donors choosing which towns festival their money will go towards."Mr Lowriersquos son was the Braw Lad in Galashiels last year ndash and now Mr Lowrie is running through each town that Robbie visited."My sister loved the common riding season, and was so proud and excited for Robbie ahead of the big day last year, said Mr Lowrie."Sadly, she died just a few weeks before and didnrsquot get the chance to watch her nephew carry out his duties."Donations will help common riding committees make up for not being able to hold fundraisers due to the coronavirus pandemic, says Mr Lowrie.However,donors prefer, they can ask for their money to go to the childrens ward at the Borders General Hospitalndash another cause close to Mr Lowriersquos heart.He said: "The staff in ward  were fantastic with my daughter Jorga, who had a number of blood transfusions during the first six years of her le, due to having a rare blood disorder."Thankfully, she is well on the road to recovery, and wersquore very grateful to all the staff in the ward. Its great to be able to give something back."Mr Lowrie, who plays football for Selkirk Victoria AFC, has already gone the distance in Hawick, Selkirk and Melrose ndash and will arrive in Peebles tomorrow .His online GoFundMe campaign has proved a success over the last few weeks.A total of pound, has been donated by  people [as at .am, June ], and the fundraiser has been shared  times on social media."The majority of money so far has been donated to either ward  at the BGH or the Braw Ladsrsquo Gathering committee of Galashiels," said Mr Lowrie."Im keen to raise as much awareness as possible for the cause so that other towns can benefit too."Other towns on the list are Jedburgh, Duns, Innerleithen, Kelso, Musselburgh, Lauder and Coldstream.And on June , Mr Lowrie will run km in Galashiels, one year after Robbie led proceedings.He said: "Hopefully, Ill be able to get some sort of [socially distanced] crowd to cheer me on as Im going up Scott Street, where the horses would normally go."Im trying to convince Robbie to join me for a part of it, but hes not agreed to anything yet."Although Innerleithen does not have a common riding, they do have a games week in July.And as Donna lived much of her le there, Mr Lowrie thought it would be fitting for the towns festival to be able to benefit.He said: "Ive been blown away with peoples generosity."Id like to say a big thank you as well to local companies ndash including Tesco in Galashiels, who donated blister packs, water and Haribos."The blister packs will definitely be needed, as Ive been running in the same pair of shoes for months and one of the toes has worn away!Details of the fundraiser can be found here.

title: selkirk-community-council-holds-first-online-meeting
story: SELKIRK Community Council hosted its first online annual general meetingyesterday evening .During the meeting, all current members remained in their posts, with council chairman Alistair Pattullo the first to be retained.Reflecting on the coronavirus outbreak, Mr Pattullo told members: "Since our last meeting, our lives have changed."He went on to praise the work of the Selkirk Response Team, which treasurer Judith Thompson reported had received a total of pound, over the previous year.Mr Pattullo particularly commended the efforts of Graham Easton for helping residents during the virus crisis.He added: "Im sure this community council will continue to do the best for the community."After confirming appointments to community council roles, items of regular business were raised.Topics included:Concerns over water continuing to run off Forest Mill at Dunsdale RoadDavid Deacons suggestion that a local high school pupil should join the committeePraise for Selkirks resilience during the pandemic ndash Caroline Cochrane described the creation of face masks as "a great bit of community spirit"Ms Cochrane also outlined plans for Selkirk Farmers Market, noting local stall holders hopes that the event wouldbefore August.Ms Cochrane said there is a "lot of work to be done", adding that only food stalls will feature when the market s.For updates on future meetings, and to access the community councils AGM  minutes ndash when available ndash visit: www.selkirkcommunitycouncil

title: bus-travel-borders-edinburgh---service-resume
